A video showing a group of mothers from the western city of Sanandaj condemning the death sentences was shared on social media. On Wednesday, a Twitter account published handwritten notes by the men appealing for public support. â€œDonâ€™t let them kill us,â€� read one note, which went viral on social media. Friends of the families of the men said one of them â€“ Kazemi â€“ had been suspended upside down by interrogators and shown a video of his brother being tortured. Kazemi was also allegedly subjected to mock executions at least 15 times. In an audio message recorded inside Dastgerd prison, Kazemi said: â€œI swear to God I am innocent. I didnâ€™t have any weapons on me. They [security forces] kept beating me and ordering me to say this weapon is mine â€¦ I told them I would say whatever they wanted, just please leave my family alone. I did whatever they wanted because of the torture.â€� Kazemiâ€™s sister said in an interview with the Shargh newspaper before the executions: â€œWe demand to see evidence. They should present evidence that shows my brother was present at the time of the murder. The only evidence in this case is statements by others; one says â€˜I heard from someone that it was Majidâ€™, and another says that â€˜Bahmani told us that Majid was thereâ€™.â€� â€œWe donâ€™t intend to cause trouble,â€� she added. â€œWe are neither against the supreme leadership [Iranian government] nor anyone else. We just donâ€™t want our brotherâ€™s blood to be unjustly spilled.â€� At least 582 people were executed in Iran last year, the highest number since 2015 and well above the 333 recorded in 2021, IHR and the Paris-based group Together Against the Death Penalty said in a joint report in April. More than 220 people had already been executed this year, IHR said recently. Agence France-Presse contributed to this report

title: Forget Jurassic Park: inside the gorgeous David Attenborough series thatâ€™s redefining dinosaurs
lead: Prehistoric Planetâ€™s intimate, moving CGI footage is revolutionising natural history â€“ and itâ€™s presented by a national treasure. We meet the creators of a unique TV series
author: Stuart Heritage
body: Jurassic Park was released 30 years ago, but in those three decades our perception of dinosaurs has largely remained static. In the public consciousness, they were giant, scaly beasts with huge claws and teeth who spent their days chasing down victims and ripping them apart in brutal fashion. Think dinosaur and you will probably picture a primal, primitive force of unbelievable fury. And then along comes the new series of Prehistoric Planet (Apple TV+), which, in a single instant, undoes almost everything we thought we knew. The instant in question concerns the Hatzegopteryx: a vast, vicious-looking, giraffe-sized pterosaur. Had the Hatzegopteryx been depicted on screen at any point until now, it would undoubtedly have been to swoop down like a monster and gobble up its prey. But Prehistoric Planet shows us something different. It shows us Hatzegopteryxâ€™s mating ritual, which may qualify as one of the most beautiful things you will ever see. A male carefully arranges various naturally occurring trinkets around himself on the spit of an island and gently starts dancing, eyes never leaving the sky, in the vain hope that a female might pass overhead and take interest. Itâ€™s heartbreaking, lovelorn and gorgeous to watch. Hatzegopteryx â€“ who knew? â€œNothing is primitive about dinosaurs,â€� says Tim Walker, Prehistoric Planetâ€™s series producer, over a video call. â€œThey werenâ€™t lone hunters or killers. They were really social and they would have been really flamboyant because of the social mindset. Our mission, if you like, was to show the audience that these are not mindless monsters.â€� The second series marries two irresistibly compelling forces: MPC, the visual effects house that helped Jon Favreau create his photorealistic remakes of The Lion King and The Jungle Book; and BBC Studios Natural History Unit. The results of this union are astonishing. You have all the respect and scientific rigour that you would find in a traditionally shot documentary such as Planet Earth presented with thoroughly convincing CGI. After a while, you stop noticing that itâ€™s not real-life footage. Part of this is down to the producersâ€™ approach to what they depict. Mike Gunton, a Natural History Unit mainstay and the showâ€™s executive producer, says their approach stems from the horrifying sequence in Planet Earth II where an iguana hatchling runs for its life from dozens of speeding snakes. â€œThe reason that sequence felt so powerful was because it felt uncontrived,â€� says Gunton. â€œIt was very much: â€˜Oh my God, we didnâ€™t know that was going to happen!â€™ Weâ€™re definitely copying that feeling here. The CGI can do anything, but weâ€™ve tried to make it feel as if we turned up to shoot one thing, but then: â€˜Oh my God! Look at this!â€™ Weâ€™ve tried to shoot and edit as if it were found footage.â€� This approach â€“ treat the camera as if it had been placed by a flesh-and-blood documentarian â€“ plays out through the series. There are T rex sequences, but donâ€™t expect any extreme closeups. When we see a T rex, Gunton explains, itâ€™s depicted as being â€œpretty much shot on the longest telephoto lens in our armouryâ€�, to stop the camera operator from being eaten. â€œItâ€™s a subtle difference, but I think itâ€™s a critical one in terms of authenticity,â€� he says. Speaking of authenticity, Prehistoric Planet presents itself with the swaggering confidence of any Natural History Unit project. What we see, we are told, is how it is. That seems like a tall order, especially when making a show set millions of years ago based on data that is constantly developing. I ask Walker how the team managed to land on what to create for the series. â€œEverything starts with the fossil record,â€� he says. â€œThatâ€™s our baseline. The show is set 66m years ago. So, if you look at the fossil record, what was around? Not just the big dinosaurs, but everything else that lived alongside. All animals have got to perform a suite of behaviours. Theyâ€™ve all got to mate, theyâ€™ve all got to eat. All this will be dictated partly by what type of animal they are and what their environments are like. Itâ€™s a combination of the fossil record, then the experience of wildlife film-makers who have observed animals in the field. And so you can start to bring all these different disciplines together, marry them with the CGI, and you build the plan.â€� This new view of dinosaurs takes some getting used to. When I first heard of Prehistoric Planet, my reaction was to write it off as a slightly jazzier version of Walking With Dinosaurs. After all, these animals are many millions of years old. What more could we have learned in the space of a couple of decades? Quite a lot, it turns out. â€œWe have a weekly scene meeting with our production team,â€� says Walker. â€œOur lead scientific consultant, Darren Naish, is part of that team. Each week, we have Dr Darrenâ€™s Dino Download, in which he gives us the latest news from palaeontology world, and we have to guess how many new dinosaurs have been described. On average, each year, over the last couple of years, a new dinosaur has been described every week.â€� That is a lot of new dinosaurs, I say. â€œWho knew that palaeontology was such a fast moving science?â€� Walker replies, with a grin. In fact, Prehistoric Planet has even helped to nudge our understanding of dinosaurs forwards a little further. â€œThereâ€™s a mosasaur sequence, where we show it jumping out of the water,â€� says Walker. â€œThe team that we were working with didnâ€™t fully know how the mosasaur could propel itself as fast as we show it. And so they set about doing a bit of academic work to find out the velocity that this particular type of animal could achieve.â€� Gunton adds: â€œThey knew the mosasaur was an ambush predator. But they werenâ€™t sure how it could generate the thrust to accelerate at such speed. They had some suspicions, so they formulated a calculation.â€� â€œLook, here it is,â€� says Walker, palpably giddy as he holds up his phone and shows me a mathematical formula that takes up his entire screen. â€œThere is extraordinary scholarship here,â€� says Gunton. â€œEvery single minute, every single second, is underpinned by serious and deep scientific interpretation. Thatâ€™s one of the things that weâ€™re super-proud of. The science and the reality of how you shoot this forces you into a position where it feels true. And we know from watching documentary, the truth of the world is always more engaging than something that we make up.â€� Realism was less important in terms of the CGI, however. The series may be consistently breathtaking, but, to sell it to viewers, Gunton and Walker found themselves having to pare it back. â€œSome of the photography that we can now do in the real world, and that weâ€™re currently doing with Planet Earth III, is insane,â€� says Gunton. â€œBut if we did that in Prehistoric Planet it would look wrong. â€œThis is a conversation weâ€™ve had with Jon Favreau. Weâ€™ve dialled down the photography, because otherwise it would have looked like a VFX show. The footage here feels more akin to what we were filming maybe eight years ago. Itâ€™s a really weird mind game to play.â€� Another thing that helps to sell the show, of course, is the participation of Sir David Attenborough, who not only narrates but also presents several sequences to camera. He is such a warm and reassuringly authoritative presence that you sense the producers could have staged a CGI dinosaur dance sequence and Attenborough would be able to convince you that it was scientifically accurate. â€œNot bad for 96,â€� says Gunton of his longtime collaborator. Attenboroughâ€™s participation was not a done deal, however. â€œHe was very assiduous,â€� says Gunton. â€œIf he was going to do this, then it had to be the last word on the matter. And it had to be all about authenticity. No fantasy. I remember the day we first showed him footage; he sat there watching on the computer, tapping his fingers. When it finished he turned to me â€“ heâ€™s so theatrical â€“ and he paused. Eventually, he said: â€˜I donâ€™t know how you could have done it any better.â€™ He works on the scripts. Heâ€™s been a fantastic asset, of course, a fantastic supporter. But also you still get notes. Heâ€™s 96 and he still gives notes.â€� Earlier this year, there were reports that the BBC series Wild Isles would be Attenboroughâ€™s last appearance filming on location. Gunton is one of his closest professional collaborators â€“ and perhaps his most qualified successor â€“ so, as we wrap up, I ask if the rumours hold any truth. â€œIâ€™ve been working with him for 35 years,â€� Gunton says. â€œThe first show I worked on with him was The Trials of Life, and the news then was that this would be David Attenboroughâ€™s final series.â€� So thatâ€™s a no? â€œThe only person who knows when itâ€™s Davidâ€™s last year is David. Heâ€™s in this project, and Iâ€™m working with him on at least two other projects in which he is a significant contributor.â€� Could one of them be Planet Earth III? â€œCould be,â€� says Gunton, grinning. â€œHeâ€™s still working and heâ€™s still amazing.â€� Prehistoric Planet Season 2 is on Apple TV+ from 22 May.

title: A Brief List of Everyone Who Died review â€“ a lifetime of loss
lead: From childhood pets to octogenarian friends, playwright Jacob Marx Rice addresses mortality in a warm and thoughtful play
author: Chris Wiegand
body: RIP Buster. Heâ€™s in a better place where he wonâ€™t have to wear that cone of shame. Still, the news is hard for five-year-old Graciela. Her petâ€™s death is the first she has encountered. She blames her parents: â€œYou made my doggy dead.â€� First itâ€™s Buster then, five years later, Grandma. As Jacob Marx Riceâ€™s play proceeds to commemorate each loved one who dies during Gracielaâ€™s life, the suspense â€“ and rising death toll â€“ momentarily evokes an Agatha Christie thriller. Yet the only mystery is the eternal one: not whodunnit but what happens afterwards. In a cast of five, Vivia Font skilfully plays Graciela from preschooler to octogenarian, ageing affectingly. One minute she is a boisterous child, the next a brittle teen, face-palming at mumâ€™s mortifying behaviour. The script subtly parallels scenes from her childhood and adulthood, and itâ€™s moving to see the daughter become a parent. A precarious balance of pain and humour is deftly retained throughout, with astute observations on the profound and banal ways that death disrupts our lives. â€œDeath should come by raven or something. Not a Yahoo inbox,â€� says 23-year-old Graciela. When she hits her 70s, the news proliferates â€“ the illnesses named but not the deceased. Heart attack, diabetes, cancer. The causes of death bring to mind Forced Entertainmentâ€™s staggering First Night, in which they were disturbingly assigned to individual audience members. The difference here is that, despite a cosy setup that seats actors among the front row as if in a family room, the playâ€™s grand sweep and high concept sometimes keep us at a remove. The play is staged with sensitivity by Alex Howarth but as Gracielaâ€™s family grows over the decades you lose the sense of interior lives that marked Howarthâ€™s heart-rending (and less sentimental) Cassie and the Lights. A recurring ritual marks deaths through communal moments of song and snapshots (part of Rachel Sampleyâ€™s video design) shown on a gauze that also, less successfully, represents â€œthe other sideâ€�. The play is well performed by Kathryn Akin, Amelia Campbell, Alejandro De Mesa and Siphiwo Mahlentle beneath designer Alice McNicholasâ€™s golden cluster of lightbulbs that glow when a character dies. Itâ€™s a warm and thoughtful night, even if it never quite captures the impact of death on the way we live. â€¢ At the Finborough theatre, London, until 10 June

title: Glasgow up in arms over proposed entrance fee for Kibble Palace
lead: Dazzling iron-framed glasshouse has been free to visit since it opened to the public in 1873
author: Libby Brooks Scotland correspondent
body: Beneath the vaulting dome of the Kibble Palace, generations of Glaswegians have enjoyed the verdant delights of this dazzling iron-framed glasshouse that dominates the cityâ€™s Botanic Gardens. Accessible to buggies, wheelchairs and walking sticks, the Kibble is a place to meet, escape the rain, get a wee warm up, say hello to a stranger, watch the world go by. It has always been free to do so since it opened to the public in 1873. So plans announced by Glasgow city council to charge an entrance fee â€“ to help plug a Â£50m funding gap in next yearâ€™s budget left by Scottish government cuts â€“ have been met with implacable opposition by local people. The actor Tam Dean Burn, who is organising a â€œsoft occupationâ€� of the Kibble every Saturday to challenge the councilâ€™s decision, says: â€œKids have been through a lot in the last few years, especially those from deprived backgrounds, and this is a natural environment that is always changing, where they can be a bit independent.â€� â€œWe know how important green space is for mental wellbeing, how some people these days need a warm space, or older people need a place to connect. And itâ€™s those who need it most who will be hit by the charges.â€� On any given afternoon, the span of ages and interests visiting the Victorian glasshouse is striking: toddlers with their grandparents, equally entranced by the wide pool of darting carp; children chasing through the central display of antipodean tree ferns; new lovers and old friends strolling round the sculpture-lined perimeter. There are tourists admiring the orchid collection, photography students and sketching retirees. The painter Andrew Cranston is lingering by the fish pool. â€œI feel itâ€™s another erosion of civic space,â€� he says. â€œEveryone needs space to dream in, to stand and stare and not have to spend money.â€� â€œSome people say this is middle-class griping,â€� he adds â€“ the Botanics is situated in Glasgowâ€™s largely affluent West End â€“ â€œbut thatâ€™s total nonsense.â€� Cranston points out the proximity of less-well-off neighbourhoods such as Maryhill and Partick, and the way that the Kibbleâ€™s informality of entry attracts visitors from across the city. â€œIâ€™ve no objection to giving donations when you can, but charging entry is nonsensical,â€� says Sheila Penny, a nanny who has been bringing children to the Kibble for 25 years. Glasgow city council estimates that proposed charges of Â£3 for adults and Â£1.50 for children could raise about Â£185,000 annually, and says its budget â€œaimed to protect services and jobs where ever possible and has looked to deal with the funding gap by raising revenue where we canâ€�. â€œItâ€™s just another attack on common space,â€� says Sapna Agarwal, referring to recent cuts to library opening hours in the city. â€œSociety is becoming more fragmented and people are struggling in so many different ways. We need spaces where people can be together.â€� More practically, she adds: â€œItâ€™s the only free space where you can be outside in the park with small children then come in for a warm up, a snack or a nappy change.â€� Her daughter, eight-year-old Yukio, says she likes playing among the tree ferns. â€œWe used to call it â€˜the jungleâ€™ when we were younger,â€� says her friend Clem, also eight, â€œbut now itâ€™s like a really easy maze.â€� â€œI like how there are all these crazy plants from all over the world in this one spot,â€� says Duncan Carmichael, 11. His poem about the Botanic Gardens has been shared by the Keep the Kibble Free campaign as a prime example of the beneficial impact the glasshouse can have on young people. In it, Duncan, who is autistic, describes â€œthe big leaves in the palm house towering over me as I walkâ€�. His mother, Vivien Scotson, says: â€œIâ€™m a registered carer and a single mother so we are limited to free-of-charge activities. He spends hours looking at the fish and I get to see my child calm and happy. Itâ€™s quite a magical place.â€� But an entry charge on top of travel costs would turn it into an expensive day out. â€œItâ€™s saying people like us are not welcome in places like this when itâ€™s been free for over a 100 years. I think a lot of people will take this personally.â€�

title: Country pubs, cycle lanes and ghost stories: a two-wheeled weekend in Kent
lead: Marathon runner and fitness writer Miranda Larbi escapes to a Kentish cottage for long runs, cold swims, British fizz and the hair-raising history of Britainâ€™s most haunted village
author: Miranda Larbi
body: When you first cycle through the idyllic Kentish village of Pluckley, youâ€™re struck by just how English it is. The Darling Buds of May was filmed around here. You can imagine Miss Marple keeping an eye out through one of the cottage windows. Itâ€™s the kind of place that could win village of the year. Pluckley, a picture-postcard village with secrets â€¦ But thereâ€™s something else â€¦ Come out of Pluckley station and youâ€™ll hear the squeak of a sign swinging in the breeze. Thatâ€™ll be the Victorian-era hunting lodge turned award-winning pub the Dering Arms. Cycle six minutes into Pluckley proper and youâ€™ll come to St Nicolasâ€™ church, a 900-year-old building set among silent winding lanes and fields. Itâ€™s home to the White Lady (said to haunt the vault where she was buried some 500 years ago), the Red Lady, who roams the churchyard, little white dog at her feet, and another 10 or so other ghosts. Welcome to the most haunted village in Britain. Our home for the weekend, Romden Barn, is a quick cycle ride from the station, and we went via the Pluckley farm shop with its hyper-local sparkling wine, honey and heritage tomatoes. My partner Lorin and I only learned of the areaâ€™s ghostly reputation when a neighbour mentioned it the following day â€¦ just as we were setting off to check out the ruins of a 12th-century church. Not afraid of a friendly ghost or two, we proceeded with our plans â€¦ While the churches may be a little on the spooky side, the barn, nestled between Pluckley and Smarden, is stunning. Straight out of Grand Designs, itâ€™s all exposed beams, lofty ceilings, bright rooms and so much space. Sleeping at least six, it plays host to everything from big family birthday parties and friendly reunions to couplesâ€™ getaways for those of us who live in tiny flats the rest of the time. Romden is a traditional barn with all mod cons Keen runners, we had come for a weekend at Romden to finish off the last of our marathon training â€“ mapping out a simple route thatâ€™d take us through local points of interest while taking in as much greenery as possible. We wanted to stay somewhere that was accessible by public transport, where we could store bikes and â€“ most importantly â€“ had facilities for winding down and relaxing post-run. Itâ€™s tough work, clocking up the miles every weekend, especially when youâ€™re treading the same towpaths and parkrun routes. The plan was to take a fast train down from London on the Friday evening, head out on a long Saturday run somewhere entirely new, cycle to the local shops for provisions, and then spend the rest of the weekend luxuriating in the barnâ€™s hot tub with a glass (or five) of local fizz. Saturday dawned bright and sunny, and we jogged through Smarden towards St Maryâ€™s (the site of the aforementioned ruins). Every turn we made, we were greeted with another breathtaking vista or Instagram-worthy scene. On the picturesque, winding lanes, drivers are so used to cyclists, ramblers and runners, that they give all slower-moving traffic a terrifically wide berth. And, mercifully, we didnâ€™t come across Pluckleyâ€™s resident spectral highwayman or phantom coach and horses on our jog either. Calling it quits at 11 miles, we grabbed our bikes and pedalled to the farm shop for brunch provisions: vinegary Kent crisps, slabs of local bacon, fresh eggs, soft sourdough, tangy chutney â€¦ cold wine. As the Aga warmed up back at Romden, we indulged our inner Wim Hofs by stripping off and taking a plunge in the barnâ€™s cold-water pond â€“ deep breathing amid the water boatmen before dashing to the hot tub to warm back up. A full English has never tasted so good. Itâ€™s easy to explore the area on two wheels, with many destinations in cycling range Thereâ€™s plenty to do around the area with a bike â€“ all of which is carefully noted in a bumper binder curated by Romden Barnâ€™s owners, who are cyclists too and pedal a daily route around the villages. As well as going to every trouble to make the barn as comfortable as possible, including leaving us a bottle of fizz and a delicious, local pink apple juice, theyâ€™ve done their damnedest to make your experience of Kent a memorable one. Leeds Castle is an hourâ€™s cycle north, while Sissinghurst (arguably the best gardens in England) is about 45 minutes away. The seaside at Rye takes just over 90 minutes â€“ slightly longer than the cycle to the National Trustâ€™s Scotney Castle. And of course, youâ€™ve got plenty of pubs around. Cycle up to the Rose & Crown at Mundy Bois before checking out the Black Horse in Pluckley (which is next to the haunted church). Then head over to the Bell in Smarden (built in the 1500s) and finish in the Flying Horse â€“ enjoying a pint and looking on to the lush fields thatâ€™ll take you back home. Of course, thatâ€™s all assuming you actually manage to leave Romden Barn. After our full English, we found it too difficult to ignore the draw of the whirlpool bath, huge beds, Sky box and the hot tub. Lounging at Romden, surrounded by fields and birdsong with a cup of tea, we achieve real peace â€¦ and not a ghost in sight. Romden Barn comfortably accommodates six To book a stay at Romden Barn, or to find your perfect holiday home anywhere in Britain, go to cottages.com

title: Phil Jones issues emotional statement after confirming Manchester United exit
lead: Manchester Unitedâ€™s longest-serving player issued an emotional statement on Friday as he confirmed the long-expected announcement that he would leave Old Trafford in the summer
author: Tony Paley
body: Phil Jones issued an emotional statement on Friday as he confirmed the long-expected announcement that he would leave Manchester United in the summer after his contract expires. The 31-year-old defender, who joined under Sir Alex Ferguson from Blackburn Rovers in 2011 and is Unitedâ€™s longest-serving player, has managed only 13 appearances since the start of the 2019-20 season because of chronic knee trouble, with his limited appearances a constant source of comment from fans at Old Trafford and beyond. Jones was entitled to have a testimonial after a decade at the club but, aware of the frustrations that have surrounded his continued presence while not actually being present at first-team training for a year, turned it down, reportedly joking: â€œApart from my mum and dad, who else would turn up?â€� â€œItâ€™s been very difficult, the last couple of years,â€� Jones admitted in his farewell to United. â€œThereâ€™s no denying that. There is no hiding away from that. My family have been absolutely instrumental in keeping me on the straight and narrow and keeping me focused, to try to get fit and try to play more.â€� He continued: â€œIâ€™ve missed playing football. I missed it. You grow up playing football and all you want to do is play football. Itâ€™s all Iâ€™ve known, from such a young age, is to do what you love doing for a living. Iâ€™ve been fortunate enough to do that, albeit not as much as I would have liked. â€œMy time at United has been nothing short of incredible. When I decided to leave Blackburn I was desperate to show everyone what I could do at the highest level. I had a hunger inside me, I was desperate to continue that at a club that could challenge for everything. â€œI had offers from a few places, but I was waiting and waiting for the call from United. One day, on holiday, the phone rang and it was Sir Alex. I left my holiday that day; I couldnâ€™t wait to meet him. I couldnâ€™t wait to sign and, most of all, I couldnâ€™t wait to get started. There was only one club where I wanted to continue my journey in the game. â€œTo wear this shirt, even just once, to wear this badge and represent everyone associated with it, has been an honour. I wish I could have played more. I wish I could have given more to the many squads I played amongst. I will say, from the bottom of my heart, I did everything I could. I did everything the medical team asked of me.â€� Unitedâ€™s announcement on the club website concluded: â€œOur No 4 is now taking some time before deciding his next move and everybody at United would like to wish Phil the very best of luck for the future.â€�

title: How Republicans are embracing the accused subway killer Daniel Penny
lead: White former marine accused of killing Black street performer has raised more than $2m for his legal defense fund
author: Victoria Bekiempis
body: When New York City authorities charged Daniel Penny with second-degree manslaughter after placing fellow subway rider Jordan Neely in a deadly chokehold, his case quickly became a flashpoint in rightwing discourse on crime and vigilantism â€“ and the broader culture war playing out in the US in advance of the 2024 election. Penny, a white former Marine, soon raised more than $1m for his legal defense in the killing of Neely, an unhoused Black man. The sum now exceeds $2.5m. Showing how his support largely comes from the US right, the financial drive is posted on GiveSendGo, a Christian fundraising website which has also hosted efforts for rightwing vigilante Kyle Rittenhouse and far-right groups and individuals, among them January 6 insurrectionists. Numerous senior Republican politicians have joined the chorus of Pennyâ€™s defenders. Among them is Floridaâ€™s rightwing governor, Ron DeSantis, who touted Penny as a â€œGood Samaritanâ€� who merited support in a Twitter post that also managed to invoke George Soros â€“ a Holocaust survivor and funder of liberal causes whose name has become an antisemitic dog whistle. â€œWe must defeat the Soros-Funded DAs, stop the Leftâ€™s pro-criminal agenda, and take back the streets for law abiding citizens,â€� DeSantis, a likely Republican primary contender, ranted in his tweet. â€œWe stand with Good Samaritans like Daniel Penny. Letâ€™s show this Marine â€¦ Americaâ€™s got his back.â€� DeSantisâ€™s tweet also included a link to Pennyâ€™s fundraiser. Vivek Ramaswamy, a businessman seeking the Republican presidential nomination, donated $10,000 to the Penny fundraiser. He retweeted his likely primary rival DeSantis, saying: â€œI agree with this. Just donated. More of us should. We must restore the rule of law in America.â€� Ramaswamy, listing some of Neelyâ€™s past criminal offenses, said that he â€œnever faced real justice for terrorizing New Yorkersâ€� and blamed Manhattan district attorney Alvin Bragg. The fatal encounter unfolded when Neely â€“ who had struggled with homelessness and mental illness â€“ walked on to a Manhattan subway train car shouting that he was tired, hungry and ready to die. A video recorded by a freelance journalist captured riders holding Neely against the floor. Penny kept Neely in a chokehold long after Neely stopped moving and at least one rider implored him to release the man. Police officials found Neely unconscious, and he was pronounced dead at hospital. The cityâ€™s medical examiner deemed Neelyâ€™s death a homicide. While police officers detained Penny and questioned him after the incident, they quickly released him, spurring public outcry and intense scrutiny over that decision. Bragg later announced that Penny would be arraigned on a second-degree manslaughter charge and he surrendered to police on Friday. He appeared in court shortly thereafter and was released on $100,000 bail. The Florida Republican congressman Matt Gaetz echoed similar pro-Penny sentiments. â€œâ€˜Subway Supermanâ€™ Daniel Penny is a HERO,â€� Gaetz tweeted. â€œToday, I will personally be donating to his legal defense fund on GiveSendGo.â€� Kid Rock, an American rap-rock musician who has become an adamant Donald Trump booster, was among Pennyâ€™s top supporters, donating $5,000. â€œMr Penny is a hero. [Manhattan district attorney] Alvin Bragg is a POS. Kid Rock,â€� the singer, who rose to fame in the late 1990s with Bawitdaba, said in a message. Charlie Kirk, who founded the powerful conservative student organization Turning Point USA, similarly issued a call to action. â€œPlease consider supporting Daniel Pennyâ€™s legal fund against NYCâ€™s unjust prosecution. Even if heâ€™s acquitted of criminal charges, heâ€™ll likely face a civil trial, so give what you can,â€� Kirk tweeted. Jenna Ellis, an attorney who served as a senior adviser to Trump, said: â€œSupport Daniel Penny!!â€� Her tweet included three American flag emojis. Trump, the Republican presidential frontrunner who last week was found liable of sexual abuse, surprisingly did not offer concrete commentary on Penny. He did, however, demonize Neely while admitting he had seen no recording of the incident. â€œWell, I think he was in great danger and the other people in the car were in great danger. I havenâ€™t seen the tape,â€� Trump said in an interview with the Messenger that was published on Monday. â€œBut I think he was in danger. And it sounded like the other people in the car were in danger. And it also looks like [Neely] was arrested over 40 times and had lots of problems.â€� â€œSo I havenâ€™t seen the tapes. I wonâ€™t make a definitive [statement] but it looks to me like the people in that car were in great danger.â€� Attorney Ron Kuby â€“ who represented one of the Black teens whom white subway gunman Bernhard Goetz shot nearly four decades ago in an incident that also became a flashpoint in culture war discourse on crime and vigilantism, said the tenor of conversation around Neely wasnâ€™t unique. â€œWhen Bernard Goetz opened fire on four teenagers riding on a train he too became the celebrated everyman â€“ every white man â€“ whoâ€™s had enough by the right wing,â€� Kuby said. â€œItâ€™s not new, and itâ€™s not hard to explain. Your Penny is a white Marine, and his victim was a mentally ill, homeless â€¦ queer Black man. So thatâ€™s the agenda of white supremacy playing out right there.â€�

title: Monsters: A Fanâ€™s Dilemma by Claire Dederer review â€“ beauty and the beast
lead: Is it OK to love the art of a morally repugnant artist?
author: Kathryn Hughes
body: Is it OK to love a film, a book or a painting if its maker turns out to be a bad person? Not just lovable aw-shucks everyday bad, the sort who forgets to pick the kids up because he or she is too busy making art, but someone whose behaviour is immoral, illegal or both? A monster, in fact. This is the dilemma that Claire Dederer addresses in this exhilarating, gnarly inquiry into the business of separating the authorâ€™s repugnant life from his or her magnificent work. It is hardly a new topic â€“ in the middle of the last century, the proponents of New Criticism were arguing about what they called the â€œbiographical fallacyâ€� and duly concluding that the critic should set aside an artistâ€™s life and concentrate on their work alone. But then, Dederer points out tartly, they would say that, wouldnâ€™t they? As mostly elite white men, these critics were naturally inclined to hand out free passes to others for the kind of bad behaviour with which they were themselves on intimate terms â€“ parental absence, alcoholic indulgence and that impregnable self-regard that inflicts collateral damage on everyone else. Seventy years on, and the problem of what to do about great art by horrible people has roared back, taking on slightly different flavours in this age of #MeToo and social media â€œcancellationâ€�. These days Dederer finds herself wondering if itâ€™s ever OK to enjoy reruns of The Cosby Show and what to do about Picassoâ€™s Les Demoiselles dâ€™Avignon, with its â€œhot pink bodies and its grimly animal facesâ€�. Can we listen to Michael Jackson if we stick to the stuff he made in his prepubescent Jackson 5 days? Although, wait a moment, wasnâ€™t he being horribly exploited as a child worker at that point? Does that make it better or worse? And most crucially of all for Dederer, who spent her early career as a film critic, how do we solve a problem like Roman Polanski? When she rewatches Chinatown, his Oscar-winning masterpiece from 1974, is she tacitly condoning his statutory rape of a 13-year-old school girl just three years later? Polanski is a particularly knotty case, says Dederer, because his own biography is the stuff of nightmares. His mother died in Auschwitz and his pregnant wife Sharon Tate was murdered by the Manson â€œfamilyâ€� in 1969. Trying to weigh Polanskiâ€™s trauma against the â€œstainâ€� of his later criminality makes your head hurt, which is why Dederer finds herself wishing for a moral calculator that would do this kind of thinking for her. Sheâ€™d punch in all the salient biographic details and, hey presto, the machine would â€œspit out a verdictâ€� as to whether or not it is OK to carry on looking at Picassoâ€™s bashed-up renditions of his many mistresses or bop along to Michael Jackson when I Want You Back comes on the radio. The impulse to farm out the decision to an external authority sounds hopelessly naive â€“ but then, asks Dederer, isnâ€™t there something equally ridiculous about thinking that whether we choose to enjoy a particular piece of art or not is going to change anything? That we might be able to ameliorate the harm of Polanskiâ€™s violation of a schoolgirl or Picasso burning the face of his â€œmuseâ€� FranÃ§oise Gilot with a cigarette? Far more productive, she suggests, is for us to start being honest about our own monstrosity. Indeed, she believes that until we accept our own capacity for bad behaviour then we are stuck in the worst of all worlds â€“ denying ourselves the satisfaction of consuming art that moves us in ways we donâ€™t quite understand yet failing to get to grips with why we keep returning to it. To get things going, Dederer offers up her own monstrousness. She is a mother who is also a writer, which means that she has been guilty of negligence on those occasions when she has accepted invitations for residential fellowships which have taken her away from home for weeks at a time. Worse still, she has hugged herself with relieved glee while doing it. On top of this, she spent 10 years as a functioning alcoholic, which is not something that usually combines well with engaged and committed family life. Dederer doesnâ€™t go into details since this is not a confessional memoir and that is not the point. Instead she shows us her own monstrosity as a way of beginning to breakdown the imaginary cordon sanitaire we habitually draw around artists whose behaviour repels us. We can decide, in a panic of self-righteousness, to cast all their work aside and consign it to a cultural deep freeze. Or we can choose instead to keep it in full view, with gratitude and wonder that such saving beauty is still possible amid the moral grot in which we all live. â€¢ Monsters: A Fanâ€™s Dilemma is published by Hodder & Stoughton (Â£20). To support the Guardian and Observer, order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.

title: Negotiating with post-Trump Republicans is like dealing with a toddlerâ€™s tantrum
lead: While one side is happy to defecate on the floor, the other side has no choice but to clean up the mess
author: Richard Wolffe
body: They say that negotiating with a toddler is like a hostage situation: only one side of the discussion wants to defuse the crisis. Welcome to Washington in the post-Trump era, as the United States stares down the barrel of debt default. The fate of the global economy now rests in the hands of the grown-ups inside the Biden administration and the tantrum-prone children who populate the House Republican caucus. This is not a fair fight. One side is happy to defecate on the floor. The other side has no choice but to clean up the mess. The spiritual leader of this crappy caucus is of course the man-child who has built an entire post-presidency from the grievances he blathers about every day. Freewheeling in front of a televised audience of his fans on CNN last week, Donald Trump displayed the kind of mastery of finance that has led to his multiple bankruptcies over the course of his dismal career of business failures. â€œI say to the Republicans out there â€“ congressmen, senators â€“ if they donâ€™t give you massive cuts, youâ€™re going to have to do a default,â€� said the unindicted co-conspirator of an insurrection to overthrow the United States government. When pushed whether he really meant what he said about having to â€œdo a defaultâ€�, Trump just shrugged it all off. â€œWell, you might as well do it now because youâ€™ll do it later,â€� he explained. â€œBecause we have to save this country. Our country is dying. Our country is being destroyed by stupid people, by very stupid people.â€� Now if thereâ€™s one thing Trump and his Trumpy Republicans understand, itâ€™s the thinking of very stupid people. Who else would know that very stupid people are going to do something very stupid like a totally unnecessary default on sovereign debt? So you may as well get ahead of them by doing something very stupid like that yourself, sooner rather than later. To be clear, Trump and his Trumpy Republicans think this whole default thing is just some kind of brain fog. â€œItâ€™s really psychological more than anything else,â€� he told CNN. â€œAnd it could be very bad. It could be maybe nothing. Maybe itâ€™s â€“ you have a bad week or a bad day.â€� A bad week, a bad day â€“ or even, and just hear me out here, a bad couple of generations. Hereâ€™s what happened last time the House Republicans drove the global economy to the edge of debt default, back in 2011 when President Obama was grappling with the Tea Party Republicans. The credit ratings agencies downgraded United States debt for the first time in 70 years, which ended up costing the government more money to sustain its debt. A brilliant outcome. To be clear, the debt ceiling debate is not about the grotesque size of federal spending. That is the budget debate, and both parties have enjoyed spending massive amounts of debt over many decades. The debt ceiling is a technical measure to decide whether the Congress â€“ which approved of those budgets â€“ is going to pay its own bills. This is not a new crisis or even a fast-moving one. It is as predictably slow as it is gob-smackingly dumb. The United States actually reached its debt limit in January, around the time the Democrats handed over the House to the Republicans after last yearâ€™s congressional elections. Yes, they could have lifted the debt ceiling themselves, but decided to lob the grenade to the next Congress. So for the last four months, treasury officials have been shuffling around large pots of cash to stay within their limit of what is now a $31.4tn debt. Apparently we have not yet reached the gazillion phase of American borrowing. These financial shenanigans will exhaust themselves in all of two weeks, give or take a few days or weeks. Some Republicans have suggested that treasury could just pick and choose a few bills to leave unpaid. Those Republicans canâ€™t spell insolvent. Trump for one knows how this is going to play out. Not because heâ€™s a genius, although clearly he thinks he is. But because he knows that only one side is going to behave like grown-ups and that side isnâ€™t his own. â€œI donâ€™t believe theyâ€™re going to do a default because I think the Democrats will absolutely cave because you donâ€™t want to have that happen,â€� he told CNN. That of course is what Obama did. And that is what Joe Biden has already indicated he will do. Earlier this week, Biden said he was â€œconfidentâ€� that there would be an agreement to avoid default. â€œWeâ€™re going to come together because thereâ€™s no alternative way to do the right thing for the country,â€� he said. â€œWe have to move on.â€� By â€œwe,â€� he meant his own Democrats. The man on the other side of the Oval Office sofa was Kevin McCarthy, the catastrophically weak House speaker, whose majority â€“ and job â€“ rests on the internal monologues of just a handful of Trumpy Republicans. The side that needs to be house-trained is sadly, barely, in control of the House. If McCarthy loses just four or more of his own 222 members, he is doomed. Which means we are all doomed. Until recently, Democrats inside the White House and Congress have insisted on a â€œcleanâ€� bill to raise the debt ceiling. They abandoned that position this week, as Biden toyed with the idea of a bunch of budget cuts. Republicans want to see $4.8tn of cuts, mostly to stuff that only Democrats seem to care about, like feeding poor working families or dealing with the climate crisis. Democrats are witnessing the slow centrification of their own White House. Team Biden is preparing to junk the last two years of progressive policies in favor of some classic pandering to the right ahead of a tight presidential election. After trying to look tough on migrants on the southern border, they now want to look tough on spending â€“ especially spending on social welfare. This is the kind of politics that inspires and satisfies nobody. McCarthy cannot win the debt ceiling battle because his Trumpy caucus thinks the cuts are not enough and itâ€™s fine to default. Biden cannot win because he is ready to dump his partyâ€™s principles and priorities to avoid default and defeat next year. Somewhere in the middle of this, working families that need support will find there is less food each month and higher medical bills. But the debt default crisis will dissipate, until the next one, and most swing voters donâ€™t need to worry about the people whose safety net is about to get shredded. Itâ€™s really psychological more than anything else. Richard Wolffe is a Guardian US columnist

title: Lend your plants some support â€“ theyâ€™ll do better with something to lean on
lead: Donâ€™t wait until your climbers become unwieldy before giving them a helping hand
author: Claire Ratinon
body: This is a busy time on my veg patch. The spring crops are established and the summer ones are finding their feet. The soft fruit plants â€“ raspberries, redcurrants and blackcurrants â€“ are starting to swell while the self-sown nasturtiums, calendula and poached egg plant are beginning to take up more space. Every day, a harvest awaits. Leaves of punchy rocket and oak-leafed lettuce leaves for a salad with dinner, and rhubarb stems shucked from their crown and stewed for dessert. Putting in support structures for your plants is a pre-emptive act, a gesture made in the hope that your crops will flourish. So, since their growth is probably gathering pace, donâ€™t wait until your plants become unwieldy before giving them something to lean on as they grow. Theyâ€™ll be healthier for it, plus it makes harvest easier. For the climbing plants â€“ beans, cucumbers, squash â€“ structures or trellises made of willow, bamboo canes or hazel are simple to construct and sturdy. I favour the classic tripod â€“ three (or four) sticks pushed into the ground and tied together at the top into a pyramid shape. A similar structure can work for peas, but add netting or chicken wire, or weave twine around the structure for their more delicate tendrils to grab hold of. I once grew my climbing beans up a discarded rose arch I found and it was as beautiful as any clambering ornamental. In the tomato bed, stakes can be pushed into the ground an inch away from the indeterminate tomato plants and tied loosely to their stems; they will thicken as they grow upwards. Add more ties as the season progresses so plants can rely on the stake when they bear fruit. One of my priorities is to encourage the surrounding ecosystem to thrive by welcoming all the buzzing, crawling, singing creatures to join me in the garden. But another is to ensure thereâ€™s a crop to pick â€“ I use bird-proof netting to stop blackbirds eating all my soft fruit as it ripens and to stop pigeons stripping brassicas of their leaves. Insect-proof mesh can be deployed to keep flea beetles from peppering brassicas with holes, but in my experience itâ€™s more effective at preventing carrot root fly from laying eggs and producing the larvae that feed on the roots. Another horticultural material is shade netting. When growing in direct sun, especially in the heat of summer, lettuce plants have a tendency to bolt, rushing to produce flowers and seeds; this also makes the leaves less palatable. Shade netting can offer some protection and keep plants cropping for longer.

title: Turn off your email, get the packing right â€“ and never, ever play Monopoly: 15 tips for a happy holiday
lead: Hereâ€™s how to master the art of holidaying, whoever youâ€™re going away with
author: Jess Cartner-Morley
body: Spend your money on space rather than travel â€œAll mammals get aggressive when crowded,â€� says clinical psychologist Linda Blair. â€œSave money on long-distance travel and invest instead in generously sized accommodation where you wonâ€™t be on top of each other. Everyone needs a place to retreat to â€“ itâ€™s how you keep stress levels down.â€� Do not aim for perfection In the adverts, holidays are a magical montage of tinkling laughter and adorable children splashing in the water watched by Mum and Dad holding hands on twin sun loungers. In real life, all the loungers are taken by 7.30am and the kids are drenching everyone by dive-bombing in to the pool while you chase them with a bottle of sun lotion. But thatâ€™s OK. The pressure to have a perfect holiday is a massive buzzkill. Stuff goes wrong when you travel: trains are cancelled, someone gets an upset stomach, the tent leaks. Holidays are about spending time with people you care about, having new experiences and relishing life in all its authentic, messy glory. Donâ€™t sweat it. Know your audience Peace and isolation may be delicious to you but deathly dull to your kids. Granny might want to do the sights while you prefer kayaking. Or the other way around. The teenagers do not need to see the cathedral. It doesnâ€™t matter. Itâ€™s their holiday, too. Ditto going On A Walk, although â€“ pro tip â€“ if you call it a hike they are more likely to be enthusiastic. Remember that teenagers have a different circadian rhythm and genuinely need lie-ins. Be honest: do you actually like beaches? Sandy beaches look so pretty in photographs, but a lot of people â€“ me! â€“ find sand super annoying. An inland spot with a pool or near a river or lake might suit you better, and be cheaper. Also, do you really want full-on summer heat or would somewhere more temperate, where you can walk and explore without fainting, be better? The point is to think about what you actually want rather than passively scrolling Instagram, where holidays always look amazing. How active do you want to be? Are you a â€œhigh peakâ€� or a â€œno valleyâ€� holiday person? A high-peak holiday is all about exciting activities; a â€œno valleyâ€� break has no â€œlowâ€� moments, and maximizes relaxation, fun and being pampered, even if thereâ€™s little change from one day to the next. Do not buy sunglasses at the airport Nobody makes good retail choices in an airport, so this is not a good time to drop Â£150 on designer shades just because you are overexcited and also deranged from getting up at 5am. The only things you should buy in an airport are forgotten toiletries, snacks or a fragrance you already love. If the plane is delayed, buy a Â£3 crossword book and some crisps. Give yourself permission to waste time â€œLeisure canâ€™t be true leisure if you are constantly trying to make the most of it,â€� says Oliver Burkeman, author of Four Thousand Weeks: Time and How to Use It. â€œWe need to learn to waste time in order to enjoy it. The holiday has cost you money and time â€¦ but it can get strangely joyless if you fixate on trying to visit all the sights, or if you think of your holiday as being about resting in preparation for working hard when you get home.â€� For the first few days of a holiday, I am too restless to actually take it easy, so I pour my energy into doing recces of the area and local shops to stock up on wine and snacks until I wind down a bit. Clothes are the least important bit of packing â€œI had a magical holiday thanks to my perfectly colour-coordinated capsule wardrobe,â€� said literally no one ever. Holiday dressing is my favourite kind, and I own way more kaftans and cute sandals than I could ever need, but clothes are the least impactful element of your suitcase when it comes to making a holiday go right. Essentials are: Uno (the only card game everyone likes); aerosol-spray sunscreen that doesnâ€™t take 20 minutes to rub in; an extra phone charger and two more plug adapters than you think you need; headphone splitters so two children can watch on the same screen; an insulated water bottle that will keep your water cool; and a bug-bite zapper (the best fiver you will ever spend in Boots). I have a friend who packs a portable wifi extender for Airbnbs with sketchy internet connection. Going as a couple? Donâ€™t brand it â€˜romanticâ€™ Spa treatments for two, honeymoon-y tables on the beach â€¦ Trying to be romantic all the time is likely to make you feel more self-conscious than sexy. Plan to have fun together instead of scheduling five days of staring into each otherâ€™s eyes. Pick a location based on a shared interest. If you both love food, go to San SebastiÃ¡n and wander the old town sampling pintxos. If you first bonded over your love of Wes Anderson, take your half-frame cameras on a train journey in search of picturesque European cities. If itâ€™s your first holiday together, somewhere new to both of you (definitely not somewhere either of you has been with an ex) is less loaded than somewhere one of you had a great time last year. Itâ€™s sweet that your new boyfriend wants to teach you to surf, but spending two days coughing up seawater is not sexy. Donâ€™t get into a holiday rut Military historians say generals tend to fight the previous war â€“ and lose the next one as a result. If you are the holiday booker, you are the general, and a common trap is focusing too much on what went well and badly last summer and ending up with a holiday that would have been perfect a year ago. People can change a lot in a year â€“ think about what you like doing now. Travelling with a little one? Take the buggy A pre-dinner stroll around town might buy you a meal in peace while they nap. Also, a piece of blackout lining that you can drape over flimsy holiday-home curtains is worth it not to be up at 6am. If you have small children, travelling light is a mugâ€™s game. Manage the takeoff and landing By this I mean the first and last days. Blair says that rather than planning to catch up sleep while on holiday, you should aim to nap more than usual in the days before you leave. The extra sleep can help to prevent frayed tempers when you do get away. Burkeman advises planning to make your journey home as smooth as possible: â€œIf you think carefully about how to handle the end point, your holiday is more likely to stay in your memory as wonderful.â€� Before you set off on holiday, figure out the journey home â€“ so download the train timetable, print the boarding passes and put a pint of milk in the freezer. Download a group-spending app Splitwise is a good one. You input what each person spends and it keeps a record, avoiding someone doing sums at the end of every dinner. If some of you have kids and some donâ€™t, or some drink and some donâ€™t, or some are on a tighter budget, chat about how to split costs before the holiday â€“ better that way than at the end of a dinner when someone ordered the lobster and everyone else is silently seething.On a family holiday, donâ€™t overstretch yourselves financially then get frustrated with children for not being grateful. Children, bless them, are ungrateful little buggers by nature. Keep house visits short and sweet An invitation to stay in someone elseâ€™s house is hugely generous. Just be mindful that you will need to sing for your supper. Itâ€™s not really on to ignore your hosts while you snog on the sofa or sleep all day. A lavish gift isnâ€™t important; bringing good vibes is. Smiles and positive energy will get you invited back sooner than a Diptyque candle. Do not have an argument to â€˜clear the airâ€™ Your beloved canâ€™t follow Google Maps so youâ€™ve taken a 40-minute detour to the restaurant, and now your new espadrilles are rubbing and you are starving. Irritation is the most easily accessible emotion, but take a breath and remember how much you love the person who is driving you insane. Holiday rows have a habit of lingering in the memory. If one is rumbling, first, slow down on the alcohol. Talk about something else â€“ anything else â€“ for a bit. It takes about 20 minutes for strong emotions to dissipate, so chat about the menu and let the clouds pass over. Move email to the last page of your phone Not seeing that little envelope icon every time you pull out your phone makes a huge difference to being able to switch off. Make sure the person feeding your cat etc knows to WhatsApp you instead of emailing, and then put on an out-of-office. Be consistent: if you have said you arenâ€™t going to respond to emails, donâ€™t pick up your phone and get involved in what is going on at the office. If you are renting a place, ask lots of questions Not sure if itâ€™s done with a fisheye lens or witchcraft, but photos can be devilishly misleading. Ask as many tricky questions as possible, says Serena Cook, founder of Deliciously Sorted Ibiza. Is there shade around the pool? How big is the smallest bedroom? Is the garden overlooked? â€œThey will tell you the good stuff, but you need to know the downsides too.â€� Try to establish contact with the property owner before your holiday. Theyâ€™re your best source of local recommendations, and a good rapport can make things smoother if anything goes wrong. Be lazy â€“ except about exercise Exercise works up an appetite for all that holiday eating, plus youâ€™ll feel better about yourself when you get home, plus it will install good associations with exercise, which means you are more likely to keep the good habits up. Also, everyone needs some me-time, and a run or swim is perfect for this. If I am reading by the pool, leave me alone Try to divide up cooking, driving and childcare in a way that plays to everyoneâ€™s strengths. I love to cook and am super happy to spend a chunk of the day planning, shopping for and making lunch. And hopefully there is someone who doesnâ€™t hate playing stupid ball games with kids, because if you disturb me when Iâ€™m having a lovely time with my new Curtis Sittenfeld novel, I may have to kill you. Field each player in his or her strongest position. Relax, delegate and let some things slide Two weeks spent making beds and hanging up wet towels is not a holiday even if you are in a bikini. Let some things slide. Tell kids to rinse their swim things in the shower with them and hang them out. Leave the heavy-going books at home and pack what you will enjoy. Tilt your face to the sun when you drink your first coffee of the day; take a nap in the shade when itâ€™s hot. And never play Monopoly Ever. Even if itâ€™s raining. Not unless you actively want to throw a hand grenade into the room.

title: Montana TikTok users denounce ban: â€˜We have terrible roads but theyâ€™re banning an appâ€™
lead: Young users question whether law tied to national security concerns will take effect in January as planned
author: Alaina Demopoulos
body: On Wednesday, a 30-year-old influencer named Kylie Nelson signed a deal with TikTok to promote the app on her page. A few hours later, she learned that the state of Montana had passed a law banning TikTok. â€œNow Iâ€™m wondering: what do we do here?â€� said Nelson, who lives in Billings and is a full-time content creator. â€œAbout 60% to 70% of my brand collaborations are with TikTok. So, yeah, Iâ€™m pretty bummed out by the news.â€� Nelson has over 206,000 TikTok followers and estimates that she will make about $60,000 through her influencing this year. Since she quit her job to become a content creator, most of her income relies on the appâ€™s existence. Lawmakers across the country have threatened to ban TikTok, but Montana became the first state to go through with the idea this week. Under the new rule, signed into law by the Republican governor, Greg Gianforte, mobile app stores are banned from offering the app to users starting next year. Nelson is skeptical that the law will go into effect. â€œIâ€™m going to believe itâ€™s banned when itâ€™s actually banned next January,â€� she said. â€œUntil then, Iâ€™m going to talk with my talent agency and TikTok to come up with a full game plan.â€� It is not just income Nelson stands to lose. Most of her posts give inspiration for mid-size fashion lovers, or people who fit into clothing larger than sizes 0-8 but smaller than a size 12. Itâ€™s one of the many niche groups that has found a platform on the app. â€œThe very first thing I thought about when I heard of the ban was the community of women that Iâ€™ve built,â€� Nelson said. â€œWeâ€™re supporting each other to feel confident in our clothes.â€� TikTok is owned by ByteDance, a Chinese company, and has come under scrutiny for its ties to the country. Politicians on both sides of the aisle, from the Biden administration to Donald Trump, have expressed concerns over national security and the potential of TikTok sharing user data with China. Christian W Poole, a 20-year-old from Bozeman, got his first 100,000 followers in high school by rating Montana towns on a scale from 1 to 10. (Lincoln and Virginia City were his top picks.) He now has 418,500 followers on the app, where he dubs himself â€œthe unofficial ambassador for the state of Montanaâ€�. Poole said that his stateâ€™s government had larger issues to tackle than TikTok. â€œItâ€™s so goofy to target them,â€� he said. â€œWe have terrible infrastructure; last year we had massive flooding that took out bridges and roads. There are so many other issues that nobodyâ€™s talking about, but theyâ€™re focusing on banning an entertainment app because theyâ€™re afraid of China mining data that the US already mines itself.â€� TikTok remains extraordinarily popular among young Americans; it has over 100 million users in the US. Representatives for TikTok told the AP that more than 200,000 people in Montana alone use the app. One day after the bill was signed, content creators front the state began posting under the hashtag #montanalovestiktok, which has been viewed over 68,000 times. â€œIt doesnâ€™t seem like this bill has any support among the public,â€� Poole said. â€œWell, maybe older audiences, and Governor Gianforte is pandering to them. The average person in Montana doesnâ€™t really care.â€� Poole will continue to use the app. â€œTikTok is my favorite hobby,â€� he said. â€œIt gets me some money, but I donâ€™t monetize it too much. I want to make people laugh and relate to me. If I lost the avenue to do that in January, that would suck, but right now Iâ€™m focusing on what I have.â€� Under the law, users will not face any punishment for accessing TikTok, but app stores like Apple and Android, plus TikTok itself, would face a fine of $10,000 per day every time someone â€œis offered the abilityâ€� to access or download the app. TikTok planned to challenge the law, which a spokesperson said violated first amendment rights. â€œWe want to reassure Montanans that they can continue using TikTok to express themselves, earn a living, and find community as we continue working to defend the rights of our users inside and outside of Montana,â€� the spokesperson said in a statement. One survey conducted by the website Casino.org asked over 2,000 Montana-based content creators whether they would continue to use the platform post-ban; 35% said they intended to. The users will have to circumvent the law by using VPNs or proxies to use the app, which would leave them vulnerable to cyber-attacks. Nelson does not know what she will do if the law goes into effect. â€œThe VPN thing is intriguing to me, but Iâ€™m also a rule-follower, so Iâ€™d have a hard time doing that,â€� she said. As bans against TikTok ramp up, ByteDance has started to push Lemon8, its newer video and photo-sharing app. Nelson said she might move her content there. â€œThere is always going to be a new app that comes out,â€� she said. â€œItâ€™s kind of like how Instagram faded out and TikTok came in. Maybe next up is Lemon8.â€�

title: Houseplant of the week: monkey tail cactus
lead: Looking for a plant pet? This cute desert native is soft enough to stroke
author: Gynelle Leon
body: Why will I love it? Cleistocactus colademononis is a desert-native cactus and the closest youâ€™ll get to a plant pet: its long, thin stems are covered in soft white spines that resemble a monkeyâ€™s tail and are soft enough to stroke. Light or shade? Bright, indirect light. But it can tolerate some direct light too. Where should I put it? Place it in a tall planter or hang it from the ceiling in your living room to show off its beauty. How do I keep it alive? This cactus prefers to be kept on the dry side, so allow the soil to dry out completely before watering. During the winter, itâ€™s best to water sparingly as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Use a well-draining cactus mix, as this will help prevent root rot. Feed monthly during the growing season (spring/summer) with a balanced, water-soluble fertiliser. Did you know â€¦ The monkey tail cactus can grow up to a metre tall and produces small, bright red flowers in the spring. Its white spines are modified leaves that are designed to protect the plant from predators and to help it retain moisture in its arid environment. In Bolivia, its stems are used as a natural remedy for various ailments, including headaches, burns and rheumatism.

title: Chinese police detain woman for supporting comedian who joked about military
lead: Comic Li Haoshi made joke about soldiers that Beijing authorities deemed insulting
author: Helen Davidson in Taipei and Chi Hui Lin
body: Chinese police detained a woman for posting online in support of the comedian who was punished for making a joke that authorities said insulted the Chinese military. According to state media, the 34-year-old woman, reportedly surnamed Shi, admitted to police that she had posted â€œinappropriateâ€� comments about Chinese soldiers. Shiâ€™s post was in reaction to the stiff punishment delivered to Li Haoshi, also known as House, over a joke about two dogs chasing a squirrel reminding him of one of Xi Jinpingâ€™s military slogan. After an audio recording of the joke went viral, Beijing police launched an investigation under a 2021 law which criminalised insulting Chinaâ€™s military, the Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army. â€œWe will never allow any company or individual use the Chinese capital as a stage to wantonly slander the glorious image of the PLA,â€� Chinaâ€™s ministry of culture and tourism bureau said. His employer was fined Â£1.68m. Related hashtags were viewed more than 2bn times, with some comments supportive of the comic. Li later apologised on Weibo, which is strictly monitored and censored, and said he felt â€œdeeply guilty and regretfulâ€� about the joke, before his account was suspended. On Tuesday, in a post that appears to have been taken down, Shi posted: â€œWhy should HOUSE be banned? Arenâ€™t all soldier brothers just dog brothers?â€� The Global Times reported she was put in administrative detention, which allows police to hold someone for up to 15 days without charge for a minor public order offence. On Weibo, news about Shi had been read about 4m times by Friday, with most comments generally angry at her for supporting Li. â€œWithout the military, how could you have a stable life today? You are not grateful for your words, you are not a human being!â€� said one. â€œThey never thought that they would be insulted by some bad-minded youngsters years later for having defended the country,â€� said another. The furore over Liâ€™s joke has prompted some comedy operators to cancel shows, and spread fear among performers about crossing government lines. One overseas Chinese comic said Liâ€™s joke had nothing to do with politics, and that the case made her feel â€œshocked and desperateâ€�. â€œI didnâ€™t think that the red line would be so easily crossed and that there would be no mercy when it was,â€� said the comic, who requested anonymity. â€œEven internet users, who have no public influence, are being pursued â€¦ The whole atmosphere has become not just official censorship, but [also] self-censorship and mutual censorship. For a long time, in this way, one thinks and creates with fear. I feel that all areas of creativity and expression have no room for survival.â€�

title: Phillip Schofieldâ€™s brother jailed for sexually abusing teenage boy
lead: Timothy Schofield, 54, sentenced to 12 years for offences committed while a civilian police worker
author: Steven Morris
body: The brother of the television presenter Phillip Schofield has been jailed for 12 years after being convicted of sexually abusing a vulnerable teenage boy over a three-year period. Timothy Schofield, 54, who was a civilian police worker with the Avon and Somerset force at the time of the abuse, was found guilty of 11 sexual offences involving a child. In his victim personal statement, the complainant said he had felt trapped by Schofield and the â€œripplesâ€� of his offences continued to caused deep hurt. He said: â€œBefore Tim was arrested, I felt I had no freedom. I often felt panic, stress and fear. I felt like I was trapped in a loop of fear and anxiety of the abuse happening again.â€� But he said there had been little respite: â€œI feel more blunt, I feel more bitter, I feel numb to life. I know I should feel really happy or really sad but I donâ€™t have the ability to emotionally react. I feel like Iâ€™m watching everything crumble before me â€¦ Iâ€™ve had to fake everything for so long.â€� Sentencing him at Bristol crown court, Mrs Justice Cutts told Schofield: â€œYou exploited his innocence for your own sexual gratification.â€� She said the complainant thought he had to do what Schofield wanted because he was worried about his temper. She said: â€œHe felt forced to do what you wanted, trapped and unable to escape. He felt he couldnâ€™t tell anyone and did not do so for many years. You took away his ability to be the teenager he should have been: carefree, relaxed, happy. You became utterly obsessed with him. â€œYour actions have had a devastating impact. You thought only of yourself. I have not heard a word of genuine remorse, only self-pity.â€� Grey-haired and bearded, Schofield shook his head and appeared tearful during the judgeâ€™s sentencing remarks. Schofield was convicted of two counts of sexual activity with a child, three of causing a child to engage in sexual activity, three of causing a child to watch sexual activity and three of engaging in sexual activity in the presence of a child. The offences took place between October 2016 and October 2019. The court was told that some of the pornography was â€œextremeâ€� and involved violence. Robin Shellard, prosecuting, said aggravating factors included a â€œsignificant degree of planningâ€� and the fact that he gave the complainant alcohol to make him more â€œmalleableâ€�. Peter Binder, defending, said Schofield had no previous convictions and described his client as â€œsocially isolatedâ€� and â€œdeeply troubledâ€�. â€œTo his eternal shame he lost semblance of a moral compass,â€� the barrister said. A jury at Exeter crown court was told the offences emerged after the complainant was persuaded to see two counsellors and revealed what had happened. The police were alerted and Schofield was arrested within 48 hours at his home in Bath. Schofield was based at Avon and Somerset police headquarters and was suspended from duty in December 2021 when the allegations were first made. Following his convictions, a misconduct hearing took place and he was dismissed without notice. In a statement issued after the verdicts last month, Phillip Schofield said he was disowning his brother. â€œThese are despicable crimes,â€� he said. â€œAs far as I am concerned, I no longer have a brother.â€� He added: â€œIf any crime had ever been confessed to me by my brother, I would have acted immediately to protect the victim and their family.â€� Det Insp Keith Smith of Avon and Somerset police said the offences committed by Schofield were not connected to his employment with the police as an IT worker but the fact he was a member of staff will be â€œof great concernâ€� to the public. He said: â€œWe want to be absolutely clear, weâ€™re on a mission to root out all those who betray the standards and values weâ€™re committed to uphold. The public must be able to trust police officers and staff, and protecting this bond of trust is our priority.â€� A spokesperson for the UK childrenâ€™s charity NSPCC said: â€œThe victim in this case has shown real courage in coming forward to report what happened and giving evidence in court, and we hope he is receiving all the support he needs to help him move on with his life.â€�

title: Do football teams with nothing to play for really end up â€˜on the beachâ€™?
lead: As crunch time arrives for some clubs and others have nothing but pride at stake, we examine how likely focus is to falter
author: Michael Butler
body: You may have noticed that Napoli swept to their first Scudetto in 33 years this month with five matches remaining. You may not have noticed that the newly crowned champions lost 2-0 at promoted Monza last weekend. With the title secured, no European campaign to worry about and no record points tally to chase or international manager to impress for this summer, could Napoliâ€™s players (and staff) be accused of being â€œon the beachâ€�? Defined loosely as downing tools, the theory is not confined to football â€“ as any teacher with a VHS in their hand at the end of term will attest â€“ but with a few vital and not-so-vital matches left of the season, this is the area of most interest. Despite the arguments of some fans grumbling on the way to this weekâ€™s penultimate round of Premier League fixtures, the reality is that being on the beach is a myth. There is simply too much to be gained, or lost, from a playerâ€™s motivation not being what it should be. Data is king and, with all the performance gadgets and dozens of cameras homed in on every turn and sprint, it becomes patently obvious if a player is not giving his all. The transfer market is ruthless and managers can bump an underwhelming player out of the team quicker than you can say Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang. Contracts and even goal bonuses are too lucrative for somebody not to give a monkeyâ€™s. Harry Redknappâ€™s career as a player and a manager stretches back to the mid-60s, and he will be in the dugout again on Saturday for a charity match at Loftus Road for the Kiyan Prince Foundation. Whether itâ€™s been his side or his opponents, heâ€™s been in plenty of situations where a team could be said to be on the beach Redknapp feels this is a nonsense. â€œPremier League players are fully focused,â€� the 76-year-old says. â€œThey train hard, 99% are not drinkers, they look after themselves. Thereâ€™s too much at stake and the crowd are not going to stand for it. When youâ€™ve got 40,000 people screaming at you, giving you abuse if you donâ€™t put a shift in, how can you go out and not try? Quite often, they play better in games where thereâ€™s nothing to play for, because thereâ€™s no pressure. I remember when I was at Southampton in 2004-05, in a relegation battle with Norwich, and they got beat 6-0 by Fulham, who were mid-table.â€� There are countless examples to disprove the rule of being on the beach and Redknapp was involved in one of the most notable. On the final day of the 1994-95 season, Manchester United needed a win at Redknappâ€™s mid-table West Ham to have any hope of the title. With rivals Blackburn drawing at Liverpool the door opened for Manchester United. All they needed was a win at the Hammers, but a sensational defensive display denied Sir Alex Fergusonâ€™s side, even though Harryâ€™s son Jamie scored a fine free-kick to beat Blackburn 2-1. â€œThat was some day,â€� Redknapp says. â€œA great day for football. I brought another centre-back on, with 15 minutes to go, and Fergie got the hump with me. I strung five across the back, and we were keeping them out at all costs. We worked our socks off that day. Ludek Miklosko was great, wasnâ€™t he? â€œWe were delighted. You donâ€™t think about Man United. Youâ€™re not there to help Man United â€“ we werenâ€™t bothered if they won the league or not. Youâ€™re there to get a result for West Ham give the fans a good last day of the season.â€� He adds: â€œHereâ€™s another one. Tottenham won at [Manchester] City to qualify for the Champions League in 2009-10. A few days later, we went to Burnley, went 2-0 up but got beat 4-2. I gave them the biggest bollocking theyâ€™ve ever had in their life. We had nothing to play for, but you want to win.â€� Standards have risen in the Premier League because the playersâ€™ lifestyles have become sanitised. Itâ€™s true that players live relatively boring lives. Players go to bed on time, hire private chefs, donâ€™t go out. Professionalism reigns. Slogans such as â€œFAIL TO PREPARE, PREPARE TO FAILâ€� are tattooed on to arms, or inscribed on walls at the training ground. Anyone who doesnâ€™t adhere to the strict guidelines is run out of town. There can, however, be external factors. At this stage of the season, teams can easily be weakened by injuries or managers choosing to rest players for a cup tie. Often at this stage a few players are worried about picking up a knock before a European Championship or World Cup. Lots of things can affect a playerâ€™s commitment, but it is a more random, sporadic set of reasons than a broad trend of players not trying. â€œA lot of it is the luck of the draw,â€� Redknapp says. â€œYou may play a team that is involved in a cup competition. David Moyes had a semi-final in Europe this week so he rested most of his West Ham team at Brentford, and they got beat. So you can certainly strike lucky on the run-in. Iâ€™d rather play a team that is a distracted than one that has nothing to play for.â€� Fans of Manchester City and Brighton may be pleased their teams are facing Chelsea (who canâ€™t finish higher than 10th) and Southampton (already relegated) respectively on Sunday. But City and Brighton will likely win not because their opponents are on the beach. Itâ€™s probably more to do with the fact Chelsea and Saints are just not very good.

title: Corleone: the Sicilian town trying to break free of its mobster past
lead: Mood is changing in town that spent half a century terrorised into silence under mafia bosses
author: Lorenzo Tondo in Corleone. Photographs by Francesco Faraci
body: If it werenâ€™t called Corleone, this small, quaint town would appear to visitors as one of many others of the Sicilian hinterland: groups of elderly people strolling in a semi-deserted square, rows of low sand-coloured houses and a 16th-century church on the highest hill. It would be difficult to imagine that for almost half a century it was the stronghold of the mafiaâ€™s bloodiest and most powerful clan, and the fiefdom of Italyâ€™s most feared mobster, TotÃ² Riina. Immortalised in cinema and literature by The Godfather, it became synonymous with organised crime, even if the bosses who once governed it â€“ Riina, Luciano Leggio and Bernardo Provenzano â€“ are now dead. But, tired of dealing with a name that has become a curse, Corleone is struggling to escape its mobster past. The local government last week voted for a resolution demanding the â€œswift removalâ€� of Giuseppe Salvatore Riina, 46, the third-born of the former boss of bosses, who returned in April after eight years in jail for extortion, money laundering and mafia association. The resolution describes Riina Jr as an â€œunwelcome fellow citizenâ€�, whose family caused â€œreputational damage to the cityâ€�. The mayor, NicolÃ² Nicolosi, said the local government had decided to â€œsound an alarmâ€�, though the ultimate decision rested with magistrates in Palermo or even the national government. â€œRiina Jr, once back in town, was welcomed with a cordial attitude by the people and this a dangerous sign in a period where the community was finally moving on, leaving its mafia past behind. The truth is that most of them are being polite because they still fear him. The reality is that they are tired of him and his family,â€� he says. â€œSometimes people point out to me that the person next to me at the bar was related to Provenzano or Riina,â€� says Dario Triolo, whose father, Ugo Triolo, a lawyer, was murdered by the mafia in 1978. â€œBut the truth is, I donâ€™t feel anything for these people.
