title: Chess: Caruana edges Bucharest while Ding narrowly avoids finishing bottom
lead: The US champion finished on 5.5/9, half a point ahead of a quartet of pursuers, while the new world champion, fatigued from his title match exertions, escaped last place only in the final round
author: Leonard Barden
body: Fabiano Caruana edged out a quartet of elite rivals by half a point in the Superbet Classic at Bucharest, as the US champion added to his long list of international victories. The first stage of the Grand Chess Tour was a low scoring tournament, where the 30-year-old won two games and drew seven. It was a subdued performance compared to Caruanaâ€™s youthful peak at the 2014 Sinquefield Cup, where he won seven games in a row and recorded a 3098 rating result, which is still the best in history at elite level. The 30-year-old was never under pressure, and missed winning chances against his main rival, Alireza Firouzja, before and even just after the move 40 time control. Firouzja said he would have been losing after 41 Rc7! instead of 41 Nc4? As it was, Firouzja proved the most significant gainer from the event. The Iran-born 19-year-old began rustily following his break to follow an alternative career in fashion design, then surged to lead before dropping back. Only 12 of the 45 games at Bucharest were decisive, and Firouzja was involved in five of them. He also jumped to No 2 in the live ratings. Ding Liren and Ian Nepomniachtchi competed in Bucharest just a week after their bruising world title match in Kazakhstan, and fatigue badly affected their results. Ding even got within one game of becoming the first reigning world champion to finish last in a tournament, only escaping the bottom with a good final-round win against the Romanian wildcard Bogdan Deac. On Sunday the action moves to the Superbet Rapid and Blitz at Warsaw and the return of the world No 1 and now ex-world champion, Magnus Carlsen. Recently, Carlsen has been competing mainly at the poker table, but he also kept in shape for chess last week with an impressive victory in Chess.comâ€™s Titled Tuesday. The Norwegian, 32, has abandoned his classical title, but has several other targets to attack or defend. He is the world champion in rapid and blitz so a strong performance is expected in Warsaw. There will be no showdown with Ding, however, as the classical world champion has withdrawn, citing fatigue after his gruelling marathon in Astana and his disappointing result in Bucharest. One week further on, and on Tuesday 30 May Carlsen will play his first classical game since January, when he is top seed at the traditional Norway Chess tournament in Stavanger. The Stavanger event actually starts a day earlier, when a blitz tournament decides the pairings. Stavanger will be a serious test for Carlsen. His nine opponents include the US trio of Caruana, Hikaru Nakamura and Wesley So; Anish Giri, who won at Wijk aan Zee in January defeating Carlsen en route; and a trio of ambitious teenagers. Firouzja, 19, Nodirbek Abdusattorov, 18, and Dommaraju Gukesh, 16, all have outstanding results which make them serious future contenders for the world crown. There will be another incentive for Carlsen on his home turf, pointed out by the Norwegian journalist Tarjei Svensen, who closely follows Carlsenâ€™s career. The gap on the live ratings between Carlsen and the No 2, Firouzja, is 67 points. His largest gap on an official list is 74 points, so a strong result in Stavanger could set a new record. This modest target is much more realistic than the Everest of a 2900 rating, which Carlsen has abandoned as too difficult. Sue Maroroa Jones, who died tragically at age 32 on 11 May, shortly after giving birth to her second child, Daniel, was the wife of GM Gawain Jones. She represented New Zealand in five Olympiads, England in one, held the WIM title, and scored 6/9 at the 2019 Reykjavik Open. A page has been set up where those who wish to do so can donate to help support her children. 3868: 1...R1h3! 2 Qe2 (other moves lose at least a rook) Qa4+! and White resigned because of 3 Rxa4 Rxa4+ 4 Kb1 Rh1+ and mates.

title: You be the judge: should my girlfriend stop monitoring me at the gym?
lead:
Janae thinks Jenny is too critical of her workout routine. Jenny thinks Janae should get off her phone. You decide who needs to step it up.
Find out how to get a disagreement settled or become a You be the judge juror
author: Interviews by Georgina Lawton
body: The prosecution: Janae Nothing I do at the gym is good enough for my fitness-fanatic girlfriend and itâ€™s making me feel inadequate My girlfriend, Jenny, and I go to the gym together, and sheâ€™s constantly judging me while Iâ€™m working out. She moans at me and says: â€œAll you do is go on your phone.â€� But Iâ€™m doing light exercises and chill workouts, whereas she goes hard every time with her high-interval training. Iâ€™m not sure what her problem is; itâ€™s not like Iâ€™m making her run slower by being on my phone. She often has a go at me and questions why I go with her. I say: â€œAt least Iâ€™m bloody here.â€� We go five times a week, though if it was up to me Iâ€™d probably only go twice. I donâ€™t push hard every time, but I think thatâ€™s normal â€“ and I canâ€™t believe that me going five times a week isnâ€™t good enough for Jenny. She makes out that Iâ€™m lazy. Guys, including bodybuilders, come up to me in the gym and say: â€œYour girlfriend motivates me to go harder.â€� She loves that. Sometimes I try to join in with Jennyâ€™s hardcore workouts, but she never praises me when I do. When I work out in a more chilled way, or Iâ€™m on my phone, sheâ€™ll come over and drop a snarky one-liner like, â€œHa! Classic!â€�, then walk off. I find that triggering and weâ€™ve had fights in the gym before. I hate it when she comes up behind me and watches what Iâ€™m doing on my phone, before making a comment. Itâ€™s like sheâ€™s spying. The gym should be a place for me to unwind, too. Jenny prioritises the gym over everything. Weâ€™ve been together for a year and sheâ€™s always been like this. She will wake up early, do yoga, go for a run, then go to the gym. Itâ€™s unreal. She wants a fitness-fanatic girlfriend, and I feel inadequate next to her at times. Iâ€™ll suggest going to grab a coffee or meeting people in the pub and sheâ€™ll make excuses, like â€œI donâ€™t feel well.â€� Iâ€™ll reply: â€œOh, so no gym then?â€� But sheâ€™ll still go. She needs to change tack or Iâ€™ll stop going. The defence: Jenny I like to be in and out in an hour, but Janae wastes so much time I love going to the gym, but since Iâ€™ve been with Janae Iâ€™ve made sacrifices when it comes to how I work out. The gym is my happy place, somewhere I can just put headphones in and be stress-free. Working out makes me feel better about myself. Janae also goes to the gym, but not in the same way as me. She comes to the gym to gossip with her friends, or waste time watching videos on her phone. I used to go to the gym at 7am, but Janae wants to go in the middle of the day or late at night. I prefer to get my exercise out of the way, and to relax in the evenings. Janae prefers to wake up late, have a coffee and go to the gym at 2pm. I think that is wasting the whole day, but Iâ€™m in a relationship with her so I compromise. Sometimes, before we head out, Janae will say she doesnâ€™t want to go, and I have to motivate her into getting there. I find that annoying. And when we get to the gym, Janae is often on her phone the whole time. Iâ€™ll offer to work out with her, but sheâ€™ll say she wants to do her own thing. But Iâ€™ll look over later and sheâ€™s not doing much. I like to be in and out of the gym in an hour, but Janae wants to stay for two hours. Iâ€™ll be ready to leave and sheâ€™ll say: â€œOh, can we stay longer, I havenâ€™t worked out that much.â€� Iâ€™ll say: â€œOf course you havenâ€™t, thatâ€™s because youâ€™ve been scrolling on your phone.â€� Itâ€™s not just me who thinks that Janaeâ€™s behaviour is ridiculous. She is known for wasting time. The personal trainers at the gym recognise us and often come over and ask: â€œAre you actually going to do anything today?â€� Janae needs to get serious when sheâ€™s with me. We are both fit, healthy and toned. I am slightly obsessed with the gym â€“ I just think that if youâ€™re there you may as well be fully there and workout, rather than doing nothing. Why waste your time? The jury of Guardian readers Should Jenny leave Janae to her own workout routine? Reading between the lines, I suspect Jenny has some deep-rooted insecurities that get triggered whenever she sees Janae going at a different pace. Insinuating that Janae is lazy is unhelpful: why doesnâ€™t Jenny just go to the gym alone if it bothers her that much? Tim, 41 Jenny is not guilty. The two of them have different approaches to the gym, so why not go separately? I understand they want to spend time with each other but it is making the experience less enjoyable for both of them. Rachel, 37 Itâ€™s one thing to go to the gym together, another to try to force your partner to work out the same way you do. Jenny talks about compromise, but it sounds more like she views it as a sacrifice. Maybe you should let each other just get on with it, or even not work out together at all. These kind of judgmental remarks never foster a healthy relationship. Lou, 28 Jenny should go to the gym when it suits her and do her own workout rather than imposing her habits on Janae. If Jenny doesnâ€™t stop being so judgmental it will create further resentment and undermine their relationship. Federico, 35 Jenny should stop making snide remarks. She has, however, made personal sacrifices so that they can go to the gym together. Janae is getting her endorphins from her phone, not from working out. So Janae should get off her phone or they should go separately. Sam, 30 Now you be the judge In our online poll below, tell us: should Jenny leave Janae to her own workout routine? The poll closes at 9am GMT on Thursday 25 May Last weekâ€™s result We asked if itâ€™s OK for Raoul to take Omarâ€™s favourite cafe table. 24% of you said yes â€“ Raoul is guilty 76% of you said no â€“ Raoul is innocent

title: â€˜An irresistible mix of art and genitalsâ€™: Caligula finally comes to Cannes
lead: Described by its screenwriter, Gore Vidal, as â€˜easily one of the worst films ever madeâ€™, Caligula has been re-edited by Thomas Negovan and received its premiere this week. Here, he explains his decision to revisit the swords-and-sandals shockfest
author: Catherine Bray
body: As quixotic quests go, itâ€™s a doozy: take 96 hours of raw footage filmed during one of the craziest and most tumultuous shoots in movie history and attempt to create a new version of the film described by Variety on release in 1979 as â€œa moral Holocaustâ€�. Step forward Thomas Negovan: the man who rescued Caligula. â€œThere were definitely a lot of points in the last three years where I thought I was crazy,â€� he says. â€œI thought: â€˜Is anyone going to care about this?â€™â€� But, in fact one of the most important entities in the industry, the Cannes film festival, cared very much, booking the new-and-possibly-improved version a premiere in its prestigious Cannes Classics strand, a section of the festival generally dedicated to celebrating the art of cinema at its finest. â€œAnd so all of a sudden, I thought: â€˜OK, all the therapy bills are worth it,â€™â€� says Negovan. Screened for the first time on Wednesday, the 2023 version is billed as Caligula: The Ultimate Cut, and Negovan is keen to point out that, â€œThe thing thatâ€™s bizarrely unique about it is itâ€™s almost like the version that was released in 1979 is the deviant version. Ours is closer to what was originally intended. Even the word restoration â€¦ I donâ€™t know what word works, but it isnâ€™t a restoration. I donâ€™t know what to call it.â€� A quick recap for the uninitiated: involving more drama than every season of Love Island combined, the 1979 swords-and-sandals shockfest Caligula has long been infamous as one of cinemaâ€™s most disastrous productions, its very title a byword for what can happen when a creative project spins out of control. Starring Malcolm McDowell, Helen Mirren, John Gielgud and Peter Oâ€™Toole plus a busload of porn stars, the lurid epic about the life of the mad Roman emperor Caligula, was a noble attempt to create the most explicit prestige picture in the history of the moving image. An anonymous crew member described it as â€œnot a shoot, itâ€™s the Fourth Reich. Caligula Uber Allesâ€�. The finished film itself was hardly less chaotic. With finance put together by Penthouse founder Bob Guccione, a script by the leftwing intellectual Gore Vidal, and Tinto Brass, a cult Italian film-maker famed for his erotic movies, in the directorâ€™s chair, perhaps on paper the film had a certain sort of bold logic to it. Theoretically, these three brought to the table the unique combination of hedonism, intellect and wildcard creativity that the decadent, explicit, historical epic would need. What could possibly go wrong? Everything, as it turned out, starting with a rocky development period during which Vidal fell out with everyone over changes to the script, and essentially disowned the film. Vidal would eventually call Caligula â€œeasily one of the worst films ever madeâ€�, which is quite the review to get from its screenwriter. Of course, the film didnâ€™t bear much resemblance to the screenplay Vidal wrote â€“ as director Brass announced airily during production, â€œWhat weâ€™re shooting right now is definitely not Gore Vidalâ€™s script.â€� Producer Guccione also wasnâ€™t impressed and wasnâ€™t shy about saying so: â€œIâ€™ve made the worst mistake in my life asking Tinto Brass to direct the film.â€� For Negovan, the biggest tragedy of the original film is that the actors were left high and dry when they stepped on set and again when the film was assembled in a messy and contentious edit. Mirren, whose character gives birth in stirrups that leave nothing to the imagination (on stage in front of an audience), called the experience â€œan irresistible mix of art and genitalsâ€� akin to going into Danteâ€™s Inferno. Negovan believes that the original can fairly be described as â€œthe clickbait editâ€� â€“ in the sense that all the most extreme line-readings were favoured over subtler moments, which is fun in the moment, but doesnâ€™t help the actors. His north star throughout the project was McDowellâ€™s performance, which he felt was particularly undersold by the original cut. â€œLike, of course, Clockwork Orange is brilliant. But itâ€™s not the same range that he has in Caligula. I feel like this is the best performance that Malcolm ever gave.â€� There is something moving about Negovanâ€™s quest to honour McDowellâ€™s performance. Thereâ€™s not much the recut can do about the script and iffy camerawork, which are all part of the charm. But Negovan has unearthed a much clearer sense of a character arc, from Caligula as wary young man genuflecting to the mad emperor Tiberius (Peter Oâ€™Toole, on wonderful form), to a joyful freshly minted tyrant, through to the increasing cruelty and disintegration of his reason as he is driven mad by power. Modern audiences, attuned to reality television and the way that an unfavourable edit can create an entirely different version of someoneâ€™s personality, are well-positioned to be more sensitive to the effect that the â€œclickbaitâ€� choices in the original edit has on the film as a whole. Which is not to say that this isnâ€™t the film fans know and love. Caligulaâ€™s strengths â€“ the elaborate sets (particularly the head-chopping machine), the OTT costumes, the beautiful way that it is lit â€“ are still present and correct. As are the multiple orgies, the infamous fisting scene, the copious nudity and the genuine shock of some of the violence. At the Cannes premiere of the new version, there were some walkouts following the scene where Caligula rapes both bride and bridegroom at a wedding; anyone expecting a purely silly cult movie may be surprised at how dark and upsetting some of it is â€“ and always has been. Caligula has an undeniable power to it, as an object as much as a film â€“ it is a fiction feature and a documentary of a particular place, time and confluence of different creative energies, and this new version is a compelling testament to that.

title: If swing voters were terrified of the climate crisis, ministers would take it seriously | Gaby Hinsliff
lead: The effort to stay below 1.5C needs to be a battle people feel we can win, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
author: Gaby Hinsliff
body: The end of the world is nigh, again. And as usual, itâ€™s being greeted largely with a shrug. Perhaps you felt a prick of unease as you scrolled the headlines, or half listened over breakfast to some radio debate about the fact that sometime in the next four years the planet is likely to breach the 1.5C rise in global temperature that we have long been told is the tipping point to avoid. (Although this time the breach should be only temporary, the World Meteorological Organisation report stresses that it still takes us into uncharted waters, and if nothing changes the world is likely to cross this dangerous threshold more and more often in future.) Perhaps you even felt rage or frustration that itâ€™s taking everyone else so long to wake up. But the chances are that most people will have forgotten it by lunchtime. YouGovâ€™s regular tracker poll finds Britons are still more worried about immigration, which almost a third consider the single most important issue currently facing the country, than about climate and the environment. Being a Nobel-worthy climate scientist these days must feel frustratingly like being one of those prophets of doom parading down the high street in a sandwich board, yelling at oblivious shoppers that judgment day is coming, with the exception that this time it really might be. If swing voters were as viscerally scared of flood, fire and catastrophic crop failure as they seem to be of people leaving Calais in dinghies, governments would be turning themselves inside out battling the rising temperature. Just look at the mad, economically self-lacerating lengths the Tories have been willing to go to for the past seven years in the name of supposedly â€œtaking back controlâ€� over our borders, and at how frightened Labour still is of contradicting them. Imagine if Westminster pounced on every global heating forecast like it will on next weekâ€™s immigration figures, expected to show another rise to record levels; if green issues stirred the same primal emotions as Brexitersâ€™ blue passports. But though the nation says it cares when specifically prodded â€“ three-quarters of adults said they were worried about the climate crisis when asked by the Office for National Statistics â€“ somehow we donâ€™t follow through by punishing politicians who fail to deliver. Allow yourself to think about the potential consequences of our collective feebleness, and theyâ€™re terrifying. But for some reason â€“ arguably because theyâ€™re terrifying â€“ we mostly donâ€™t let ourselves think about it very often. A psychologist would argue that the brainâ€™s natural defences against anxiety are strong, and in this case unhelpfully so. Weâ€™re hardwired to respond to imminent physical threats rather than abstract or distant ones; and, crucially, to run away from anything too big to fight. These survival instincts served humans well in conflict with charging mammoths, but not so much against the kind of abstract but existential risks potentially posed by the climate crisis, hyperintelligent AI or the prospect of antibiotic resistance rendering modern drugs useless. Add in our speciesâ€™ natural bias towards optimism â€“ the sunny belief that somethingâ€™s bound to turn up, or that someone in authority will presumably be along any minute to take charge â€“ and we are stunningly ill-equipped to deal with pending apocalypses of any kind. No doubt the media could do more to shove this particular crisis in everyoneâ€™s faces. But with apologies to those many Guardian readers who genuinely long to see climate issues covered in greater depth, journalists can lead a horse to water but they canâ€™t stop it drinking something more relaxing in its lunch hour. The joy and curse of online news is that every newspaper can now see exactly what people are reading: we know how many people skim the headlines of serious stories theyâ€™ll later swear they read, before devouring every word about Phil â€˜nâ€™ Holly at war on the This Morning sofa. And the inconvenient truth, to coin a phrase, is that at the time of writing I can see more Guardian readers are engrossed by Harry and Meghanâ€™s battle with the paparazzi than by the breaching of the 1.5C threshold. Meanwhile, on Twitter, where users joyfully unconstrained by mainstream media agendas can post about whatever matters most to them, the current trending topics are Kylie Minogue and some basketball game in the US. Melting ice sheets? Meh. Some things are just too big to get your head around. What looks on the face of it like apathy may be better understood as being overwhelmed, a sort of sagging mental exhaustion; the same feeling that makes you collapse on the sofa with a takeaway again when you know perfectly well you would live longer if you went to the gym. Itâ€™s not too late yet. The lesson from the pandemic is that people can be surprisingly willing to make sacrifices for the public good, if we think that everyone else is doing it and if the rewards are clear. Staying at home to save the NHS was, of course, the noble thing to do, but crucially it also made you much less likely to die of Covid yourself, and within weeks it was gratifyingly obvious that it was working as case numbers began to fall. The fight to stay below 1.5C needs to feel like the next national crusade, a battle we are capable of winning and which is therefore worth joining in. There is something oddly puzzling about this governmentâ€™s apparent reluctance to sing its own praises over net zero: Britain evidently isnâ€™t decarbonising fast enough, but it still reduced its emissions faster than any other country in the world between 2010 and 2020, a success many Conservatives now seem strangely embarrassed to mention. Crucially, households need to know what is in it for them if they give up their gas boilers or petrol cars â€“ which in practice means more generous financial subsidies and incentives to cushion the costs of switching, plus investment in the infrastructure to back it up, from car-charging points and battery factories to an army of properly trained heating engineers. But with one in five voters already saying they think the government spends too much on climate and environment policies, political parties wonâ€™t risk spending billions more without a clear signal that this really is how we want our taxes spent. And so we go, round and round in an endless circle of dithering. It isnâ€™t rising global temperatures that threaten us in the end so much as the eternal human tendency to put off endlessly until tomorrow that which we canâ€™t quite face doing today. What the science is increasingly urgently trying to tell us, much as we may not want to listen, is that we can no longer be sure exactly how many tomorrows we have left. Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? title: Brandy Clark: Brandy Clark review â€“ country provocateur holds too much back on faltering fourth album
lead: There are some gorgeous songs here, and some inventive arrangements, but the wit and honesty of her previous work seems diminished
author: Shaad D'Souza
body: For years, Brandy Clark has been one of country musicâ€™s most reliable provocateurs. She writes witty songs about characters with endearing quirks: the woman who would kill her cheating partner if not for the fact that she knows the prison jumpsuit wouldnâ€™t suit her; the wild child who issues the simple ultimatum: â€œIf you want the girl next door / Then go next door.â€� Clarkâ€™s self-titled fourth album, produced by US singer-songwriter Brandi Carlile, is supposedly her rawest since her 2013 debut 12 Stories. That may be true â€“ there are gorgeous songs here about Clarkâ€™s Pacific north-west home and her family â€“ but it often feels as if she has mistaken seriousness for honesty. Aside from a few lovely ballads, such as the sparse Buried and plaintive maybe-breakup song Come Back to Me, most of these songs feel anonymous. A line like this, from 2020â€™s Pawn Shop â€“ â€œSomeone told me it cost a lot / Man, ainâ€™t that the truthâ€� â€“ feels far more revealing than â€œThereâ€™s a blue sky / Up above the cloudsâ€� on this albumâ€™s Ceciliaâ€™s Song. When the lyricism falters, Carlileâ€™s production often picks up the slack: Tell Her You Donâ€™t Love Her, built around fingerpicked guitar and muffled drums, offers an inventive counterpoint to Clarkâ€™s rich vocal melody; Take Mine, on which Clark sings over Mellotron, walks a similar line between intimacy and gravitas. The song that really sticks is the opener, Ainâ€™t Enough Rocks, on which Clark writes vividly about a girl who conspires to kill her abusive father. Clark tosses off the songâ€™s chorus like a grizzled onlooker: â€œThere ainâ€™t enough rocks to drown that pain.â€� Itâ€™s a tantalising glimpse of the Clark that lies underneath.

title: Please do touch: Norwich Sainsbury Centre asks visitors to interact with art
lead: Centre wants people to â€˜release the powerâ€™ of living entities through interaction and lift museums out of Victorian era
author: Harriet Sherwood
body: Instead of â€œdo not touchâ€�, visitors to the Sainsbury Centre in Norwich are invited to stroke the cool contours of Henry Mooreâ€™s Mother and Child, and urged to close their eyes and recall their first memory of being held and protected as an infant. In an accompanying guide relayed through an app, Jago Cooper, the centreâ€™s executive director, says: â€œArt isnâ€™t a set of symbols to be read, itâ€™s an emotional state of mind â€¦ If you can access that emotional connection, you can release the power of this living entity.â€� Mooreâ€™s 1932 sculpture plays a leading role in what is billed as a groundbreaking concept at the huge museum and gallery on the edge of the University of East Anglia campus. The Sainsbury Centre is marking its 50th anniversary by becoming, it says, the first museum to â€œunderstand art as a living entityâ€�. According to Cooper, the museum world is a little bit stuck in a Victorian-era model. â€œThat model is based on the idea that art and material culture is treated as property. A museum owns this property, and the public can come and benefit. But it doesnâ€™t allow you the real emotional power of [these] amazing manifestations of human creativity.â€� Cooper and his team have spent the past 18 months preparing ways for visitors to the centre to forge a relationship with art rather than simply looking at it. They can become a living exhibit in a glass showcase under 12 spotlights, surrounded by an â€œaudienceâ€� of sculptures and paintings. They can sway gently in a hammock beneath a suspended portrait by Alberto Giacometti of his brother Diego in what Cooper describes as a â€œdiscombobulatingâ€� experience. They can listen to the sound of a 200-year-old MÄ�ori flute, dance with first millennium Tang dynasty figurines, and create their own artworks. â€œWe are trying to reconceptualise what a museum is,â€� said Cooper. â€œWe want people to have a different emotional relationship with art. Great art is the physical embodiment of some of the greatest individuals, movements, societies and cultures that have ever existed. And if you can find a way of connecting with them, thatâ€™s an amazing experience.â€� Not all of the 5,000 works in the centreâ€™s collection were suitable for touching and other interaction, said Cooper. â€œLots of stuff will remain in cases, whenever we think conditions or contact with people could be damaging. But anything we feel can be and wants to be touched will be touched.â€� Henry Moore had told Robert Sainsbury, the centreâ€™s founder, that anyone who thought they could sell his art without touching it knew nothing about sculpture, Cooper said. Continual touching of Mother and Child would give it a patina, â€œbut that, for me, is part of the ageing process. Iâ€™m not trying to preserve it in a pristine state â€¦ Art isnâ€™t something frozen.â€� The Sainsbury Centre was created as a home for works collected by Robert Sainsbury, the son of the grocery entrepreneur, and his wife, Lisa. The younger Sainsbury introduced pensions and sickness benefits for shop staff and supported the postwar governmentâ€™s creation of the welfare state. The centre was designed by Norman Foster. In March, it became the first museum to introduce a â€œpay if and what you canâ€� entrance policy across the board. Previously it earned Â£350,000 a year from ticket sales. Major national museums that offer free entry to their permanent collections increasingly rely on revenue from high-profile â€œblockbusterâ€� shows.

title: Andy Rourke, bassist for the Smiths, dies aged 59
lead: Musician described as â€˜supremely giftedâ€™ by bandmate Johnny Marr had suffered long illness with pancreatic cancer
author: Ben Beaumont-Thomas
body: Andy Rourke, the bassist for indie legends the Smiths, has died aged 59. The news was announced by guitarist Johnny Marr on social media, who wrote: â€œIt is with deep sadness that we announce the passing of Andy Rourke after a lengthy illness with pancreatic cancer. Andy will be remembered as a kind and beautiful soul by those who knew him and as a supremely gifted musician by music fans. We request privacy at this sad time.â€� Rourke played on the Smithsâ€™ classic back catalogue including hits such as This Charming Man and There Is a Light That Never Goes Out â€“ both classic examples of his often boldly melodic style â€“ as well as on solo songs for frontman Morrissey after the group disbanded. He also played in the supergroup Freebass with two other celebrated Mancunian bass guitarists, New Orderâ€™s Peter Hook and the Stone Rosesâ€™ Mani, and recorded with SinÃ©ad Oâ€™Connor, the Pretenders, Ian Brown and was in the group DARK with the Cranberries vocalist Dolores Oâ€™Riordan. The Smiths formed around the partnership of Marr and Morrissey in 1982. Bassist Steve Pomfret joined, replaced by Dale Hibbert, who played the Smithsâ€™ first gig but was replaced thereafter by Rourke, a school friend of Marr since the age of 11 â€“ the pair had formed a short-lived earlier band, Freak Party. â€œWe were best friends, going everywhere together,â€� Marr said in a written tribute to Rourke. â€œWhen we were 15 I moved into his house with him and his three brothers and I soon came to realise that my mate was one of those rare people that absolutely no one doesnâ€™t like. Andy and I spent all our time studying music, having fun and working on becoming the best musicians we could possibly be.â€� The Smiths recorded their first demo in their classic lineup later that year, including songs such as What Difference Does It Make? which set out the core Smiths sound: waspish vocals from Morrissey, complex and ringing lead guitar from Marr, and a strident, technically brilliant rhythm section in Rourke and drummer Mike Joyce, with Rourke in melodic interplay with Marr and â€“ on tracks such as Barbarism Begins at Home â€“ playing funky bass solos. It was a sound that still defines British indie music of the 1980s, and it resulted in four classic albums â€“ The Smiths, Meat Is Murder, The Queen Is Dead and Strangeways, Here We Come â€“ as well as acclaimed one-off singles. Rourke struggled with heroin use and was arrested for possession in 1986. He was fired from the band, rejoining after two weeks (his brief replacement, Craig Gannon, stayed with the band for a spell, moving to rhythm guitar). â€œYou start getting a bunch of money and donâ€™t know what to do. You start spending it on drugs,â€� Rourke later said. Marr left in 1987, precipitating the bandâ€™s split shortly afterwards. â€œWhen he left the impact was huge and I think we were all traumatised and probably still are,â€� Rourke said in 2022. â€œNo one knew how to react. I didnâ€™t know whether to call him or leave him alone. It was a really awful time, horrible, for everyone concerned.â€� Rourke played on solo Morrissey songs in 1989 such as The Last of the Famous International Playboys and Interesting Drug, which Joyce said in retrospect was â€œa big kick in the eye for Johnny â€¦ I felt like I had betrayed him so it was a long while before we spoke againâ€�. Rourke and Joyce took Morrissey and Marr to court in 1989, arguing they were owed an equal share of earnings having only earned 10% each of the groupâ€™s performance and recording royalties. Rourke quickly settled for a lump sum of Â£83,000, while Joyce continued with the lawsuit and was awarded around Â£1m in backdated royalties and 25% thereafter; the case famously featured the judgeâ€™s description of Morrissey as â€œdevious, truculent and unreliableâ€�. Rourke later filed for bankruptcy, in 1999. As well as the aforementioned collaborations, Rourke later played with another celebrated Mancunian musician, Badly Drawn Boy, and joined his touring band. His most recent project was Blitz Vega, a band with Kav Sandhu of the Happy Mondays. Tributes have been paid to Rourke online, including by Suede bassist Mat Osman who described Rourke as â€œa total one-off â€“ a rare bassist whose sound you could recognise straight awayâ€�. The Charlatansâ€™ Tim Burgess called him â€œan inspirational musician with a style that made so many of us pick up a bass guitarâ€�. Marrâ€™s tribute continued: â€œWatching him play those dazzling basslines was an absolute privilege and genuinely something to behold. But one time which always comes to mind was when I sat next to him at the mixing desk watching him play his bass on the song The Queen Is Dead. It was so impressive that I said to myself: â€˜Iâ€™ll never forget this moment.â€™â€�

title: Afternoon Update: Tasering of 95-year-old woman under investigation; Stan Grant steps down; and falling for a sex worker
lead: Clare Nowland remains in a critical condition in hospital after the incident at her Cooma aged care home
author: Antoun Issa
body: Good afternoon. More details have emerged on the shocking police Tasering of a frail 95-year-old woman with dementia. Clare Nowland, who weighs 43kg and moves with the assistance of a walking frame, had left her room at an aged care facility in the early hours of the morning and gone to the kitchen. There, she found the steak knife police allege she was wielding at the time off-duty officers arrived. That led to her being Tasered by a senior constable. Nowland remains in a critical decision and the homicide squad is now investigating the incident. The police officer responsible is having their duties reviewed and currently not working. Top news Aged care Taser outrage | Calls are mounting for an independent investigation into the incident. â€œPolice should never investigate police,â€� the NSW Council for Civil Liberties president, Josh Pallas, said. The stateâ€™s Law Enforcement Conduct Commission said it was â€œindependently monitoringâ€� the internal police investigation. The NSW assistant police commissioner, Peter Cotter, said that â€œno officer, not one of us, is above the law and all our actions will be scrutinised robustlyâ€�. â€˜Horrificâ€™ allegations from WA youth detention facility | A child allegedly being hit in the head with chairs by two officers is one of the allegations contained in 58 letters of complaint tabled in the WA parliament about the Banksia Hill facility and Casuarina prisonâ€™s Unit 18. Stan Grant stands down from Q+A | The host is stepping aside from the show after receiving racist abuse which has increased since he spoke on the ABC panel show about the coronation. The ABC has lodged an official complaint with Twitter about the â€œrelentless racial filthâ€� Grant is subjected to after every episode. Earthquake near New Caledonia | A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck south-east of Loyalty Islands in New Caledonia, triggering a tsunami warning for nearby Pacific nations. Albanese at G7 | The prime minister is being urged to take a stand against nuclear weapons at this weekendâ€™s summit in Hiroshima. And not to be missed, our political editor, Katharine Murphy, has penned a lengthy essay marking Albaneseâ€™s first year in office. AMP penalised for charging dead customers | AMP has been issued a $24m court-imposed penalty after it continued to charge the accounts of more than 2,000 deceased customers after being notified of their deaths. Australian captive released by al-Qaida | Dr Ken Elliott, an 88-year-old Perth man who was kidnapped by an al-Qaida-linked group in Africa in 2016, has been released. Elliott and his wife, Jocelyn, were in their 80s when they were kidnapped by extremists in Burkina Faso. The couple had lived in the country since 1972 and had built a medical clinic in the northern town of Djibo. Disney v DeSantis | The Walt Disney Company is scrapping plans to build a nearly US$1bn corporate campus in Florida that would have housed 2,000 employees amid its ongoing legal battle with Floridaâ€™s ultra-conservative governor, Ron DeSantis. Israeli nationalists chant racist slogans | Thousands of Israeli nationalists, some of them chanting â€œDeath to Arabsâ€� and â€œWe will burn your villageâ€�, have paraded through Jerusalemâ€™s Old City in an annual celebratory day for Israelis that became one of humiliation for Palestinians living under occupation. Tupac Shakur Way | A northern California street may soon bear the name of late rapper Tupac Shakur. This week, Oaklandâ€™s city council unanimously agreed to name a part of a city street after the rapper, who called the city home in the early 1990s. In video Hidden in disused sections of Wynyard station in Sydney, underground tunnels have been transformed into a psychedelic labyrinth and are being opened up to the public for the first time for Vivid Sydney 2023. Watch the two-minute video. What they said â€¦ *** â€œAt the time she was tasered she was approaching police, it is fair to say at a slow pace. She had a walking frame. But she had a knife.â€� â€“ Peter Cotter, NSW assistant police commissioner In numbers And 56% of the decline was driven by global heating and human consumption, with warming â€œthe larger share of thatâ€�, according to a new study. Before bed read The advice columns from Eleanor Gordon-Smith never disappoint â€“ and this week is no different. A reader who is falling for a sex worker wrote seeking guidance, to which Gordon-Smith offered a thoughtful response: â€œProfessional relationships are just that â€“ professional â€“ but that doesnâ€™t stop them from being genuine sources of care. She provides intimacy in exchange for money; youâ€™re allowed to feel that intimacy.â€� Read the full question and answer. Daily word game Todayâ€™s starter word is: HAD. title: Foreign Bodies: Pandemics, Vaccines and the Health of Nations by Simon Schama review â€“ scientists to the rescue
lead: The historian offers up lessons from past pandemics in an indictment of modern leadersâ€™ response to Covid
author: Jerry Brotton
body: â€˜In the end,â€� writes Simon Schama at the beginning of his extraordinary book on pandemics old and new, â€œall history is natural history.â€� Foreign Bodies is ostensibly an account of the bacteriologists and epidemiologists who studied the natural history of infectious diseases from the late 18th to the early 20th centuries, developing vaccines and saving millions from smallpox, cholera and the plague. But as its subtitle suggests, it is also a reflection on the political and scientific conflicts of the Covid pandemic, and the failure of contemporary leaders to coordinate a scientifically driven global response to the virus. Over millennia, biological and environmental imperatives rather than states and empires have shaped human destiny. Now capitalismâ€™s degradation of the planet threatens our future survival. Zoonosis â€“ the transmission of infectious diseases from animals to humans â€“ has always bedevilled humanity, but the risks are increasing as we encroach further into natural habitats. The Global Virome project estimates that there are more than half a million unknown viruses with zoonotic potential; since 1980 sub-equatorial regions have experienced viral outbreaks every eight months; the Sars epidemic of 2003â€“4 has now been traced back to dragon-tiger-phoenix soup, a combination of palm civet meat, chrysanthemum petals and snake served in restaurants in southern China. If these facts are sobering, the response of our politicians, described with measured fury by Schama, is terrifying: now as before, international cooperation founders as national tribalism belittles science and its â€œcosmopolitanâ€� practitioners. What can history tell us about how we got here, and how to respond in the future? The answer is conveyed through a meticulous retelling of a terrible yet scientifically innovative period, beginning with the cholera pandemics of the 1850s and taking in a three-decade epidemic of bubonic plague that by the 1920s had killed a staggering 12 million people, mostly in India. White, male, Christian European colonial authorities, obsessed with segregation and sanitation, doused homes with carbolic and limewash. When that didnâ€™t work they were forced to turn to outsiders: migrants, exiles â€“ the â€œforeign bodiesâ€� of the title â€“ who challenged prevailing social and scientific assumptions. Schamaâ€™s varied cast includes Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, the first European to inoculate her children against the disease in 1721 after learning the â€œTurkey wayâ€� of variolation â€“ an early form of vaccination. We meet Adrien Proust, Marcelâ€™s father â€“ known as the â€œgeographer of epidemicsâ€� â€“ who travelled to Istanbul and Tehran, trying unsuccessfully in his 1873 essay on international hygiene to establish protocols for global public health. Exiles and Ã©migrÃ©s flit between the research institutes led by Robert Koch in Berlin and Louis Pasteur in Paris before dispersing across the globe to the frontlines of cholera and plague outbreaks in the â€œgreat game of competitive medical imperialismâ€�. By the 1890s German, French, Swiss, Russian, Japanese and English bacteriologists, doctors and nurses were to be found at centres of contagion such as Hong Kong, Singapore and most notoriously Bombay. They went in order to research and deliver vaccinations, confronting terrible conditions as well as the ignorance and suspicion of colonial officials. But, as Schama notes, it wasnâ€™t just the officials who were suspicious. He deftly captures the paradox of medicine being seen as a â€œpoisoned giftâ€� of empire: while the bacteriologists saved millions of lives, they also rode roughshod over local mores â€“ in India there was horror at the mixing of castes in hospitals and the intimate examination of women, while others worried about animal matter in the vaccines. Schama even argues that the sparks of Indian nationalism that eventually broke the Raj â€“ unified social and religious outrage that coalesced into strikes and mass demonstrations â€“ were struck during the plague of 1897. The central outsider in Foreign Bodies is the â€œculturally hybrid prodigyâ€� Waldemar Mordechai Wolff Haffkine. A Ukrainian Jew, Haffkine took up arms during the Odessa pogrom of 1881 before becoming a protege of Ã‰lie Mechnikov, the founder of immunology. Haffkine eventually developed a cholera vaccine, which he tested on himself in 1892. It worked, and by 1893 he was in India inoculating 42,000 villagers, slum dwellers and soldiers a year. In 1897 he developed a plague vaccine in Bombay, once again testing it on himself, and created the worldâ€™s first large-scale vaccine production line. By 1902 more than 2 million Indians had been protected. In November that year, however, a contaminated bottle of vaccine killed 19 people in a Punjabi village. In what became known as the Little Dreyfus affair, the British authorities hung Haffkine out to dry â€“ exhibiting barely disguised antisemitism â€“ despite evidence that he was not responsible. He was defended by the Nobel prize-winning doctor Sir Ronald Ross against â€œthe common enemy: â€˜institutional barbarismâ€™; the disrespect for science, the unconscionable inattentiveness to its illuminating knowledge, by those entrusted with public healthâ€�. Here as elsewhere echoes of the Covid era abound, leading Schama to a passionate defence of scientists like Dr Anthony Fauci. Something about the inoculators and epidemiologists, he writes, always gets â€œunder the skin of public tribunes for whom nothing, certainly not epidemiology, is politics-freeâ€�. But if societies are to fortify themselves for a zoonotic future they will need to rely on exiles and Ã©migrÃ©s, cosmopolitan and liminal individuals, those benign â€œforeign bodiesâ€� Schama describes with such careful attention. There are, in fact, â€œno foreigners, only familiars, only a single precious chain of connection that we snap at our utmost peril,â€� he declares. In doing so, he makes an urgent case for building a better future on our toxic past. â€¢ Jerry Brotton is professor of Renaissance studies at Queen Mary, University of London, and the author of A History of the World in 12 Maps (Penguin). Foreign Bodies: Pandemics, Vaccines and the Health of Nations by Simon Schama is published by Simon & Schuster (Â£30). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply. â€¢ Hear more from Simon Schama as he discusses Foreign Bodies in a livestreamed Guardian Live event at 8pm BST on Monday 24 July. Tickets available here.
